ANSWER: I'm Andy McGregor, i just got a new job so from the 1st January I'm now Deputy Chief Innovation Officer here at Jisc. Obviously it's a new job so it's still being defined but mainly it means that I'll have responsibility for defining the approach which Jisc takes to doing innovation. So my job is mainly process based. We're going to be using an approach to innovation that we've been piloting for the past year called Co-design and that's now been in used for all Jisc projects. It's my job to scale it up and to make sure the Jisc projects can work with them and all new projects come from that process. Obviously I'll oversee the projects that come out of that, the innovation projects that come out of that process. So it is a process based job now.
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: So the reason Jisc is interested in Co-design is because of the Wilson review. So in 2010 amid the financial crisis the government had a look at all the various organizations that were funded by the government. Jisc was reviewed by Wilson. That's why it's called the Wilson review and he had a number of things to say about all aspects of Jisc but innovation he had a few particular things to say about, one - that we did too many things, two - that they didn't always have the impact they should have because we were probably doing too many things and three - the process by which some of those things were agreed and started was often opaque. So Co-design as an approach innovation was a response to that to try and address some of those concerns. It does that by ensuring that key stake holders for the sector, the people who are going to use the things that innovation produces are involved in the process right from the very start and right throughout. So i don't mean that they are just consulted or they are used as a steering group. They are actually the people who we work with in a collaborative way to define what we are going to do, how are we going to do it and if we do it what success looks like for them. So last year we piloted that and the pilot was successful enough for us to scale it up. So that's the organizational reason. For me, what's led to that is, I've worked here in Jisc for about six or seven years now and throughout that time I've been involved in project in a number of different areas. I don't really have any expertise in a library background. I don't really have expertise in these. I can understand the technical stuff but I'm not technical. So i started off with repositories. I did activity data, open data, resource discovery. Quite a lot of library stuff and quite a lot of developer community stuff and a few bits around different types of innovation processes and throughout that, the common thread was, that i was interested in, were processes that define how we engage the creative people in higher education and how we engage them, how we ensure that all their creativity benefited as many people as possible. So i got more and more interested in the processes rather than the actually subjects where as my colleagues are more interested in the subject. So there research data programme manager they research data or the might be really interested in open data. I ended up being more and more interested in the processes and that's what i love focussing on and so when the Jisc leadership decided they wanted someone to look at processes, look at this new co-design approach and implement it, it was fortunate for me that i happened to have some spare time. Having expressed interest in this area that they asked me to look at and so i was able to take the outline of this process they defined, design the process and implement it. It has been a slow process over a number of years, moving away from expressing an interest in the sole object of what Jisc does and more about how Jisc does it. That's personally how Co-design came about for me.
QUESTION: So if we start going from the past through to the present. You discussed what you're going with the Co-design. What have you been doing in the last few years that has led to this idea, what is the focus of this Co-design thing and why have you come to it?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: Co-design is still very much a rough thing. It's not polished yet, it might not ever be polished. Polished is the enemy of good process because it ridgefies it and rigid hierarchies in many studies have shown to be counter-productive for innovation. So at the moment it's rough and we're developing it and polishing it but stake holders are one of the things that we have put more thought into because it's at the heart of it. As far as i see it there are three levels of engagement for stakeholders. The top is the kind of strategist level. Those are the people who are almost a kin to the organization who do say - this is what we want done, these are our needs and this is what we want done to address our needs. If you are going to successfully address these needs, this is what you need to do. So essentially they give you a strategic direction a strategic imperative for setting off in a direction. The co-designers at that level you would expect to be people like directors of IT, people like senior librarians, people like heads of E-learning, people like planners, finance directors, registrars. Essentially the people who organize in the institution, the college, the university etc who would be ultimately the people who would be signing off on the adoption of any product that was produced by innovation. They would make a decision whether to buy it. So they are the ultimate customer. They represent the people who if we're going to produce something, it has to meet their needs to be successful. So they operate at the strategist level. The next level down is the designer level. So once the strategist has identified a problem or an area of investigation or opportunity or idea. The experts from higher education institution s, from commercial organizations, from really anyone that's relevant. Jisc would convene them to work out how to go about addressing that opportunity or that problem and that would be the design stage and that could be broad array of people could be engaged in that area of design. From your expert developers through to your practitioners through to the senior managers who could again be involved in that level, people outside of the sectors such as commercial people could be involved, consultants such as Cottage Labs, people like that would be relevant there, people from government. You could imagine a vast different array. The point of that is that is supposed to be flexible diverse cause study after study shows that for innovation to work, diversity is the key ingredient to making innovation successful. So those are there and at the base level after you have designed something, you have to do it. So you've got the developer's, the doers whatever you want to call them, the implementers. The people who would go away and deliver the design. That's how i view Co-design, kind of these three stages of engagement and people could be engaged to co-design a project at any one of those levels. In the pilot we generally call people at the strategy level the co-designees, but really we've engaged a broad array of people to help us design and deliver the project and it's probably not that new to Jisc. We have always engaged widely what's different now is the systematised and the strategy level, the top level where people are involved much earlier in the decision process that they were before making it much more transparent and open in terms of what we're doing and why we're doing it and who we're doing it for.
QUESTION: Could you say a bit more about who the stake holders are that you are interested in engaging with and why you want to engage with them more?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: Well the Wilson review is one. The Wilson review did state that some Jisc processes were opaque and needed to be addressed and we did not meet customer needs. But obviously transparency has an enormous amount of benefits for innovation in general i think. One of which is diversity. Transparency enables people to be aware of what's happening and to be aware of how they can get involved and how it fits with the things they're doing and that leads to greater serendipity, greater knowledge spill over between different projects, greater diversity of input which should lead to stronger ideas. It also should lead in theory to more work done in the margins. Obviously organizations like 3M show and in fact research in general shows that lots of interesting stuff happens in the margins. So where disciplines meet or the margins where technologies meet. IN 3M for example i read that they developed a glue that was so strong it could be used for sound dampening in air craft engines. You wouldn't think that glue could do something like that but it's because they have these intersections, these margins where they are able to do interesting things like that. I think transparency is one of the key things to help leave the opportunity open for those kind of interesting things to arise in the margins. Finally i think it's important for people, obviously Jisc works with public money or institutions money so it's important for them to know purely where their money is spent and why it's spent and how it's being done. I think that is important anyway because it's a general principal. I think there are a number of reasons - Wilson, innovation reasons and just plain good management reasons. I think transparency for all of those reasons.
QUESTION: So in terms of making it more transparent and open from top to bottom, what have been the reasons for you to want to make it more transparent and open? Are there particular benefits that you are seeing there or particular social concerns that you want to meet with that?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: It has. But often not as much as feared, i have found. One example is we developed a site called Jisc Elevator. This is a site where people can put ideas, generally for small projects on the site. They do a video picture of their idea and a short description, people can vote on that idea and if successful they get funded. We have used that a couple of times now and one of the key arguments against doing Elevator, in the early days when we were said should we do it, people said people don't like sharing their ideas and i had some experience of that previously where we'd issued a call for funding and we'd tried to get, encourage people to be openly sharing ideas beforehand and only two people did. We got quite a few bits back but only two people shared them. Probably just coincidence but those two were two of the strongest bids. I don't know if you can draw any conclusions from this as it's a small number. But never the less it was interesting. But innovator, we just haven't experienced any problems. People are very happy to put their ideas on there, very happy to share them openly. These are small ideas and that may be the difference and often their not researched in a way they are innovation which you could say, innovations the step after research. Research happens to invent something and then innovation comes along to make use of that. Amongst students particularly, so the recent Elovation competition was aimed at students and they had no fear, no qualms what so ever about sharing their ideas publicly. But that does contradict with previous things where we've tried to encourage openness and it hasn't happened. Although the difference is, Elevator required openness where you share your ideas openly and people are fine with that. We encouraged it and made a requirement of it. It didn't happen so there was no incentive to do it there i guess other than for it suited your own personal way of working. Maybe it's not that common in academia. I don't want too make to many suppositions there as it's not an area i know a lot about. My experience is, certainly with Elevator, they are quite happy to share ideas generally.
QUESTION: With such a level of transparency and sharing of ideas, have you experienced any difficulties with say a more traditional scholarly approach which might involve people keeping ideas to themselves and wanting to be very much the producer of information or the lead name of a particular idea? Has that impacted your work?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: Yes. In a few cases, again we've run the Elevator twice. We've had twenty six ideas submitted the first time, the second time thirty six.So they're not enormous amounts of ideas. They didn't get an enormous amount of traction. But certainly on both times we've allowed people to comment on ideas and interesting comments have been put on. Sometimes saying this will never work, sometimes have you seen someone has already done the idea, sometimes saying I'm interested and they'd like to be involved and sometimes people have contacted people. I know for example a commercial organisation contacted one of the students before they got funded because they were interested in their idea. So yes there have been some inside benefits in terms of  making contacts, networking and sometimes learning that there's other things going on. But not perhaps as much as there could be. One of the things I'd really like to see Elevator do in terms of something we've always intended from the start is move from a demand exercise which is essentially what it is at the moment we put an idea up there and we assess the demand for it in terms of votes, to some kind of team forming exercise. I think that's how it would work in an ideal world. Someone would put an idea up there, a team would form around the idea. So people who could help deliver certain things about the idea or work together or look for an opportunity to trial the idea or offer expertise or critical mentorship for the idea any kind of addition for it and then instead of the most popular idea getting funded, the strongest team ends up getting funded around the idea. So it's a more practical instance, the level of excitement about the idea, to gauge the level of excitement and the acceptability of the idea. People who are actually dedicating time and effort or saying they will give time and effort to an idea seems to be a stronger thing than a lot of people ust saying - Yes, I quite like that. So in an ideal world if we could make that work, i think it's quite complex to make it work but in an ideal word that's how I'd like to see it working and i think that could kind of get at some of the things, the reason behind the question of what are the other benefits to being open i think that's a really interesting prospect that I'd like to have time to explore.
QUESTION: Would you say that they had a reason to do so with the Elevator? If it was mandated that they must share them and then presumably ones that get elevated get something in return for having shared them. Did you see from the sharing itself that more things emerge other than just say being the best one and being pitched as the best one? Did you get any other interesting things coming up because of the sharing going on?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: The main thing is two things, one - just a very practical issue of getting a website to do that elegantly isn't trivial. It's easy to do voting there is a drupal plugin. It's simple. Working out the mechanism to form a team is much more difficult than voting cause team formation is quite, start ups say the thing that you should always focus on you should start early and focus on the hiring of the team. Formation is one of the most important things and to expect that to coalesce magically around an idea is a bit fanciful. So i think it would need some kind of, in my experience that doesn't happen naturally. People saying - Yes, let's work together,  I've just never seen that happen before in a virtual way. I've seen it happen before in a physical way, face to face meetings. But never in a virtual way. So getting over those practical web problems initially is what I'm talking about  and then there's the issue of choice of ownership and things like that. So you've put your idea up there and then would you really ust want to have anyone available in the community to work with you on it. Probably you wouldn't want to leave it that open an idea. Here's my idea and anyone could work openly. There's a study done by musicals. I forget who it was done by and what the name of it was but they developed something called a Que something or other a Que ratio or something and what they did was they studied the success of the musicals and the make up pf the teams behind them and they found there's streets wide diversity between them. Teams who all knew each other and teams where no-one knew each other. It seemed like the sweet spot was teams that mostly knew each other but with some new people. Enough to bring in new ideas to challenge the status quo. So enough to have a successful way of working and understand each others way of working and just be successful as a team but that thirst of new ideas, challenges to break open assumptions or to try new ways of doing it. To bring in fresh new ideas and that's why i imagine you'd need on something like that, what you'd want is a team to come up with that idea and a team that's newly formed and for them to say what else do we need in terms of expertise or to be open to things they hadn't thought of or people they hadn't thought of getting involved. There is also another example of something like this where the website site like inocentive. Inocentive is an open innovation website where companies have problems and they say - we're having a problem with this chemical engineering issue and ask them to solve it. They frequently solve the problems that are up there but they frequently solve  i can't remember the exact figures but they are often solved by people in a different discipline who have seen the idea up there. So i think rather than just a complete team formation you'd want something like that probably because a complete team would be fanciful and wouldn't be ideal, a team of strangers. So i think to do it properly you'd need that kind of thought  and I'm thinking on my feet as I've not thought about it enough. I think that's what you'd need, it's one aspect of it. The second aspect of it and the more practical aspect of it is say for example you'd got a good team a team with a core of people who knew each other and all knew the idea but with some fresh new people coming in as part of the process. Then you'd have to tackle the other practical issues around how they work together and that's something we have quite a lot of experience in in Jisc. A lot of the work we do is with distributed people and distributed teams rather than co-located teams just as Jisc as an organization itself is  distributed and co-located. Most of my colleagues are elsewhere. I don't think that's uncommon now in academia. More and more teams are geographically distributed. I'm not sure it's completely optimal in a lot of ways. Certainly methodology like agile, assume and co-location.You see start ups again and start ups in innovative tech companies spend an enormous amount of time thinking about who sits where in the office and that sort of thing. I met one the other day where they change their seating arrangement every two months making sure that the right personalities are sitting with each other. So it shows co-location is incredibly important but we don't always have that luxury. So we have to find ways around that and using things like Google docs. depending on what you're doing but Google docs. Github, blogs, more corporate systems like sharepoint all that kind of thing is really important. Also finding methodologies that work is also important. So Agile works extremely well for technology projects but if you're a distributed team it's not really designed for you. Assume is co-location and meeting standard and all that kind of stuff. But you can still use the same principal in a distributed team, regular conversations, not planning in detail too far ahead, making yourself able to change direction and pivot as things happen and so i think taking all those principals and apply it to your team but you just have to be aware of that and plan slightly differently. That's even more difficult if say ninety percent of the team are located in one place and ten percent are located elsewhere. How do you stop that person becoming disconnected, marginalised? their opinions, feeling frustrated that nothing their doing is.  So there are all of those issued with team building which is why virtually going the other way is easier, it gets us somewhere. But in an ideal world, i think if we are, someone said to me just today that often in innovation people focus too much on ideas and less on execution and i worry that something like the Elevator is doing that. It is focused on ideas because there is a demand for ideas but if we really wanted to do this well we'd focus on execution. So how we form the team, who's in the team, how they work together and focusing in detail on that may well end up with better results. Initially putting all your focus on the ideas but obviously as i say it's not terribly straight forward to do that.
QUESTION: It would be quite interesting to stick with that for a bit considering what you are doing now in regards to that because the idea of collecting around the idea of getting people to commit time to it obviously gives you a bit of follow up because you have not just an idea of people who will then go and work on it. Have you any of your own ideas yet about, there's a lot of barriers to being able to form a team like that because the makeup of the way humans interact, like we may be at different universities, some of us are at organizations, some of us are commercial, some of us are in places like Jisc which has a different position to say the universities themselves and so on. Have you any ideas on how you might tackle those problems, of say three or four different people all from these different kinds of place, they all want to work on an idea but how would you help them do so? In terms of what you're thinking of, your personal interest in the idea of moving to the processes and of having this sort of Co- design and the later things going on. What do you feel are the issues that might be, like you said it might be hard to enable this, so what do you think is stopping it at the moment if anything?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: I haven't had much time to think about this. It's something i do because I'm supposed to do it. So it's what someones asked me to do! I guess it's because to some extent i think the things that we're doing and if they are done well are worthwhile. They are worth doing. If Jisc can act as an agent that can help people produce things that do help universities and colleges do things better help improve the student experience that's something that's worth doing. It's  goal. It's interesting. I guess if i was trying to be less lofty I'd say it's because your competitive i think as well cause you want to make sure that what you do is good and you've got pride in what you do and you want to make sure the things you do are good. So you spend a lot of time thinking about how to do them better. I also think that I'm very fidgety from the video you'll have noticed, but in my mind I'm very fidgety i get restless very easily and then I'm never happy I'm never satisfied. I always want to improve things and when processes improve it seems to be an itch i can't scratch. When i see something and I've done something i think OK i could have done it this way, i could have done it that way i want to do it better next time. So there's always that kind of almost personal dissatisfaction that drives you on to do things. I think all of that would be the same even if i perhaps didn't believe in it as much as i do, but i think that plus the fact i do think that what Jisc does and especially the university of higher education sector does is worthwhile and important and is exciting. I think those two together make you want to try and do things better and improve things.
QUESTION: You've clearly got a lot of interest in your work but also personally cause of the way you like to think about it, how to get people to work more like this and how to get people to collaborate. What reason do you personally have for wanting to get that? Apart from being interested in the processes that go on, what's your end goal, why is it worthwhile to try and help people to do this?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: This is something that I'm permanently dissatisfied with. I have never found anything that made me happy. The one that I'm getting enough of what i need to read, there's always a real restlessness there - how can i get more things. I mean I've very little with patience, I'm very impatient with things. I don't tend to read modular scholar research because i don't tend to operate at that level of detail. That detail tends to be extraneous to me so i want to digest it a level above. But one of the things i am dissatisfied with is sharing, that's the most frustrating thing - how do we share effectively what we've learned? So generally i suppose my methods are three things. One is haphazard clicking. I would say the majority of what i do is haphazard clicking. I'll spend happily a couple of hours a day in work or out of work on my phone or whatever just clicking away and following things. Not like I've scheduled that time but it;s just what i do. I'll read something that will lead to something that will lead to something and that haphazard clicking now is generally quite a satisfying process. I don't, because of the level of detail I'm doing i don't tend to hit upon payables that often or if i do it tends to be books I'm paying for than other forms of research. I've just realised i don't  i don't know why. So that's haphazard clicking and that can be any source but it tends to rely on free data like wikipedia and blogs, magazines, places like the Orion Radar, Harvard Business Review, newspapers and that often leads you to something more detailed like books. So last year i started to read a lot more non-fiction. I read a lot about economics and innovation and statistics and predictions and complexities and things like that and that's all lead to stuff that interests me in a personal capacity and a work capacity. The third ones is social networks. I would say that's fairly massive. Most of the really genuinely new and interesting stuff that i hadn't followed for my own interest, that's the thing about the Google filter bubble is the social networks, there's where i get things that come out of the blue and surprise me from things like twitter and so on. But the most important thing is, and this is something that i read about again and again in books on innovation is talking, it's probably the least efficient but most effective method of finding out new things. So I'll start talking to someone in the office about something i read and half understood about statistics or something and then they'll tell me something else or a book they're reading and then I'll go off  and that's generally the most effective thing. I'll tell them about something I've read that i think is brilliant and they'll tell me it's rubbish for reasons i hadn't realised. Then that will send me off down another route. When i think about trying to systematise this better and trying to do this better that's often the bit i neglect. I often don;t think that     is inefficient it's haphazard. But i do think it's the single most effective thing, i remember reading about the economics of football and they were talking about how Britain is often tactically behind other nations in British football and that was because of our separation in both in terms of geographical separation from the European continent where the innovations are coming from. Places like Holland and Spain. Spain more recently, but Holland and Germany in the seventies and so on and it's only recently that we've started to catch up. It's people talking and sharing of information that is really key to making sure that people advance and you see geographical corporations like Silicon Valley based on the fact of sharing knowledge so some innovation books call it knowledge pull over. The ability to make sure that you're in the conversation that you are networking with people who have these ideas and doing things differently to make it challenging and they said the in this book about football is you often see the most successful managers are more networked. They talked specifically about Sir Alex Ferguson and said he spends an enormous amount of time on the phone or talking to other managers in what could seem like, if you were auditing it from the outside, casual chatter but that was an essential way he found out about all sorts of other stuff that was going around you know players that were available, tactics, ideas all of that kind of stuff. As i get old from experience i realised how much more important that was. So from experience I've realised how important that was. I mean five years or ten years ago i would have said that we could do it on line better by book marking it or something like that. But now if i spend all of my day in meetings just talking to people then to some extent probably no work gets done, it's a day wasted. As long as it wasn't a frustrating conversation or going round in circles i would now envisage that to be an effective way to start sharing knowledge and learning stuff. It's a rambling answer
QUESTION: So in your own process of looking at what you've done and trying t tweak it and prove it, you've already mentioned things that you have heard about and how they act and different forms of research where you've seen people have said x and y situations will have an affect. Where do you find out about these kinds of things, how do you personally access the information that helps you to make these decisions and how do you share the things that you've learnt?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: No. But i have hopes in a number of areas just now i guess but i don't know if there is anything in particular. I am quite excited by things like the open data institute i think. That kind of practical use of open data and open data sharing is quite exciting. But i don't know how much that will impact the project we're working on at the moment. That's one of the interesting things is that a lot what we're going to be doing in the next year or so is fairly near term stuff so service development, product development that kind of stuff so things that aren't speculative or experimental but things that are fairly safe bets. So I'd of thought that because they are near term stuff then a lot of the interesting things that are developing may not have that much of an impact in the next year or so. I mean obviously things like open access and things like that are getting more prevalent and will have an interesting impact but i wonder if that's a bit further ahead than what we'll be doing now. I can't think of anything in particular that would be terribly important or interesting. That's probably shortsighted of me, one of the things that this job has taught me over the last seven years is that my predictions and opinions aren't worth anything. They have so often been proved wrong. I think that making predictions in this are is often not worth the paper they are written on. I can't think of anything in particular
QUESTION: Do you have any particular point say that are coming up in the next year or so that you'd like to discuss before we finish up? Anything that you think is going to have a large affect on the way that you access information or on they way that these projects you are working on might develop? Have you had any flashes of inspiration on how you might tackle this problem first or is there anything you're waiting to see emerge soon?
NAME: Andy

ANSWER: I am Brian Hole founder and CEO of Ubiquity Press and I'm also a PhD student at UCL and i work in doing a PhD on Archeology where I'm based in India, collecting a lot of data and so forth and that's kind of informed a lot of the work i do here as well and what i found is that i started the PhD and the company at the same time but I've ended up spending 99% of my time on the company. So that's become much more of who i am.
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I originally moved to London to go back to university and i did a masters degree at Berbeck part time. Then i always wanted to continue, i always wanted to keep studying. While i did that masters i was working for working for software development in their health science journals. But i always wanted to do study on top of that. Just to keep myself engaged and keep myself part of the research community and so forth and while working at we were building their entire platform and working a bit with the research community but not a great deal. What i found was a big publisher like that isn't very well connected with the research community and that was also very frustrating because we were building quite interesting products in the journal platforms but they weren't really available to anyone else in the community. One of the things that i suggested when i worked there was maybe we could get some of the people together and produce an open source version of their journals platform. That wasn't going to happen of course. So that's the kind of point where i started looking around at what's available for open source things and also for open access.
QUESTION: So what brought you into doing a PhD then in the end were you studied before hand or worked beforehand, where were you at?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: It was really an understanding that everything we were doing was closed. That 90% of the people in the world wouldn't have access to it That's not really what science is about or scholarship. So at the same time that i was at i was starting my PhD part time at UCL and i work with people in India predominantly and what i discovered was that no-one there could access the journals that we were producing. So i get about ten requests per month for papers and access to papers and various journals including my own stuff but other people's as well from India and that should prove the point that even though the big publishers say they make things available to people in the developing world, most of the time it's not practically the case and at the same time those people have problems publishing in our journals, difficulty in accessing our system whether it's because they don't have contacts or they are rejected during the peer review process because it's a little more tunnel visioned towards the western world etc. So there are a lot of issues there about open access itself and why that's really important.
QUESTION: So was that leap towards open source and open access driven by your desire to study or your desire to work at publication? What reasons did you have to start thinking that open access would be a good idea?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Science is about advancing knowledge through research and it's a community thing. I don't think science is done by individual islands of people. Science only advances when these people work together and share their results. It's what we talk about as a social contract of science where you have an obligation to share your research with other researchers so they can validate what you've done but also so they can build upon it and advance science more efficiently and quickly. Any publication method or any method in the way you do your science that doesn't allow that, you can go as so far to say that it's malpractice. It's not following the social contract, it's not following the arrangement we all have, that we buy into. So that's where non open access publishing in a way is not following best practice. It's actually impeding science. Especially for people in the developing world or outside of the main stream university system. Even the entire commercial sector is shut out from a lot of scientific progress.
QUESTION: So you mentioned just there that you didn't think the trouble of accessing it fitted with your idea of what science and a scholarship should be. Would you mind saying a little more about that, what is the difference there, what is it that science is that open fits with where as closed doesn't?.
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: In a company like that one, their goals are to increase their shareholder profits. They could be selling washing machines, they wouldn't really care too much. So when we set up Ubiquity Press i almost knew very much what we were doing. We are not selling just products we are all trying to change the way communication works that's really critical. But most people i think who worked in a place like us for a little bit are very disconnected from the research world. They don't meet researchers very frequently or if they do they are people at major institutions who had never considered the fact that someone couldn't access a journal.
QUESTION: Do you think then, if you can see that a lot of people who want access to this are being shut out from it or in some way excluded even if it's not necessary on purpose, what kind of an effect does that have from say your prospective of working in that company? Does that make you feel that the company is achieving it's goals or not?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes absolutely and sometimes those producers and the rest of their community. A lot of people really believe the best way, the way scientific communication works at the moment is that people are rewarded for having publications in high impact factor journals with publishers with major titles and they are not being rewarded for having the greatest possible dissemination of their work. For example if i write a paper on Polio or something and it gets that doesn't mean that someone in Bangladesh or even South Africa can read that paper. So I'm being rewarded for getting my publication out but I'm not being rewarded for good scientific communication
QUESTION: So there is a bit of a disconnect perhaps between i guess the producers of the product and the consumers of the product?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Part of it is that that's the way we've set up the system. So a system to reward, things like the impact factor and so forth, they are very western centric systems and metrics which are designed to measure things according to the publishers world really. It's saying - you've published within our closed circle of journals and you've gotten citations within that we're going to ignore the fact that science is a global enterprise and that is should have social aims and so forth and we are going to focus on metrics which are purely about that and that's reinforced all the way through the university system and the hiring processes we have and so forth.Things like the ref. as well.
QUESTION: Do you think that there is a value, you've identified a sort of problem there that it can't be accessed by others obviously scientists and people in the community are putting their findings into these kinds of places, is there some sort of value that they do get out of that, why do they do it if it's not achieving scientific communication?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: The legacy method of subscriptions and firewalls, yes it's frustrating because I mean four or five times a week there's an article that i have to spend twenty minutes getting to and it's ridiculous and quite often it's in what are supposed to be the major journals. Things like Science and even if the institution has a subscription and it can take me twenty minutes to actually access the information. That's pretty frustrating. I still come up as a student at UCI i still come up against journals that my institution doesn't have a subscription to, so i do have to e-mail authors once a month or so and that's frustrating. It's frustrating to log in and log out all the time. The fact that most of the things i cite aren't going to be readable by people in the countries I'm working in. So when i publish an article in India, most people can't access anything on my reference list and so the value of my work is then under played because it's introducing those people to new ideas but it's not enabling them to follow up on them and build upon them.
QUESTION: Given that you have started your own studies, how has that impacted your own studies that you've been doing like have you found problems accessing any information and has the current publication method helped you or hindered you in any way for what you've wanted to publish yourself?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: They can't access the things I'm citing. Obviously the data that i produce i make openly available and that kind of thing. So my actual original research is fully validateable. But yes the thing's I'm citing and so forth might not be accessible. So it's up to me partly to try and make an effort to cite open source publications but in Archeology that's not very easy. There are very few open access publications outside the ones that we publish. So if I'm going to cite world Archeology which is in an category title at that time, no-one in India will really read it.
QUESTION: So how do you think then that those people validate your work then if they can't, you've obviously got a foundation to what you've stated in your paper but how can that foundation be proved if they can't access the material?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I signed the cost of knowledge petition saying i wouldn't work without severe because of their practices in lobbying against certain sciences and so forth. So i get asked fairly frequently to contribute to special collections in their journals and i say no. I also won't publish anywhere that's not open access anymore as it would be very hypocritical. So that means that i turn down 90% of the requests to publish. Or they make a special exception and say we will allow this to be open access. There was one big collection on open Archeology which i turned down writing for and they said basically everyone else was contributing because they wanted to reach the community that was closed and to change their minds in some way. So it was kind of a counter intuitive thing. Simply by refusing they would have had to change some how. I guess that the argument is that there is an old guard of researchers who don't understand that and who are still very much are part of the world that those publications make up and if you want to reach them then you still have to publish there but that's still not solving the problem. The majority of other people can't read it at all. So it's a little bit stupid. I think also that Archeology is changing because it's a very multi disciplined area and people are working on larger collaborative projects. They are starting to publish in things like Plos 1 and because of that they are becoming a bit more exposed to the open access world. They access other science journals as well. So maybe that will change a little bit more quickly than other parts of humanities.
QUESTION: In your field then there must at least still be a majority of people who are publishing in these closed access places which is why you can't access most of the material. But obviously at least you and presumably some of your peers will have an interest in publishing in open like you described, for you that fits the method of science and you want to publish in open. What is it in your particular community, in the Archeology community that comes up in discussions where people still end up putting things in these places where their colleagues can't access it?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: You hear it sometimes. It's not even just open access. I remember going and talking to the Council for British Archeology about where they should publish data and they were just asking about electronic journals and there were people standing up and saying 'If i publish in your journal that doesn't exist..' because it's electronic. So first of all there is an old guard that need to understand electronic publishing but your question was more about.....
QUESTION: So with journals like Plos 1 coming and in more open access and the ones that you've published in yourself, have you found any emotions that people have towards, or not emotions some people may have actual arguments for or against open versus closed journals. Do you see people in your community say worrying about the quality or at least the brand of the material?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: They are at the point now where even the Institute of Archeology library is taking electronic copies over print ones. So people are getting used to reading electronically because all open access journals have always been electronic so they don't see a distinction there anymore as to whether electronic is quality or not the average researcher. But there is still a lot of problems with unusual publishers popping up. I had an e-mail yesterday from a professor at UCL asking me about a publisher called Herbert on line or something like that asking him to become an editorial board member and so there was a mass e-mail that had gone out, it wasn't personalised in any way. He was one of five thousand people who had received this e-mail probably. People do get these e-mail a lot and that does colour their thinking about it. At the same time we've got people that are absolutely fed up with and so forth. We've had companies like that refusing to allow people to put copies of their papers into the repository and basically being very untruthful about their own policies often a lot of what's legal and what's not. So we have researchers there that are coming to us and saying we want to set up an alternative to this major publishers journal, how do we go about it? We have got things in the works. So there are senior researchers who are just fed up. They are starting to hearing more and more about the big profits the publishers are making and they are looking at what they are getting in return and that's the point where they want to change things.
QUESTION: f you think do people get any kind of concerns about publishing in open access because it's not say the tradition, it's not where people expect to find quality information, do they feel that it's less quality?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: These are people who spend a lot of time peer reviewing every year and they edit special volumes of things, they are the top people in their field and then they are finding that most of their colleagues can't read the articles. There's no financial re numeration. The know the university library is spending every penny it's got on journal subscriptions to the point of bankruptcy. So they get fed up because of that.
QUESTION: So that's quite an interesting point to follow up on. What they are getting in return is starting to seem like it's not worth the cost?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Well you are to a degree because those big subscription publishers still have massive print operations. They are trying to shut them down quite quickly, i know one publisher has spent all of this year shutting down it's warehouses all around the world preparing not to be a print publishing book. They still have big costs there and even if your journal is on line only you're still subsidising those big legacy costs. They have big departments full of people managing subscriptions very manually, so you are covering that. But most of what you're paying for, is these journals are highly profitable. You are paying shareholder dividends. These companies are making forty to fifty percent profit and most of that is being paid out in dividends or to acquire other journals. That's not service you are paying for, you're paying to help those companies expand.
QUESTION: So what is the service that is still being paid for? You've mentioned that the process has become more digital so you're not talking about actual physical copies of things being produced and shipped and stored?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: More or less. I think there were more amature journals in those days but they were run quite honestly. I could be wrong I've never investigated, but I've never heard about it about people setting up publishing companies on scale and trying to cheat things a little bit. I'm not sure. There have always been lower quality journals about and some of them have been quite amateur but i think they have been run in the best interest of the community.
QUESTION: Do you think that has changed specifically in recent years because of the move to digitization? For example particularly the more traditional people that you mentioned who are concerned by say false journals popping up and asking them to be on the board. Do you get the impression that that never happened before?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: You might st up a website for the journal . You would then put the editor on board who you had never contacted or had mass e-mailed people. We see journals where they are doing call for papers but don't have editors yet, things like that. They are publishing papers without editors. They are not following peer review or anything like that. I think that people have seen the open access model with the article processing charge as a way to make some money. I don't think you could have got subscriptions early on for a journal that was low quality. Someone would say I'm not buying it. There are so many people under so much pressure to publish especially from the developing world who need to publish in the western journals that there is a feeling that you can charge a lot and not actually do the work that you're charging for and because companies like Buy Mid Central and Plos have shown that this is a sustainable model and can actually work they've said OK let's try and exploit it.
QUESTION: So where as now it's easier to produce a journal that, what's the difference, if i was to start a journal right now and i wasn't doing it at all in the interest of the community, it would be a predatory journal
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes. I mean if you publish your work and it hasn't been peer reviewed then that's no use to you theoretically. It might be in some countries where people aren't going to look critically at it, it was published in the western hemisphere and that's great. If i was a student of UCI and published in one of those journals then it would be of absolutely no value in my career.
QUESTION: So the main difference seems to be then that for the price that you pay you expect some kind of quality control, like a proper editorial board and decent peer review?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: ve just thought of a particular case study. I guess also they may have a lot of early career researchers who find it hard to get published otherwise or don't know the the hasn't spent a lot of time explaining to them where the best places to publish are. Or they promise you a very quick turn around and so forth. I've published with some of the bigger established publishers here and it's taken four years to have a paper. Four years after the initial submission I've been told i have one week for corrections.
QUESTION: Is that because there is certain value in being attached to being able to publish in what appears to be what you describe as being a western journal. If you're not western then you need to look validated?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: No it was rubbish. That was absolutely pointless and that came out in a subscription journal in the end. People e-mail me a lot about that paper and i send copies of it. By the time it came out the research was completely out of date.
QUESTION: Do you find that useful or helpful waiting four years to publish?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Absolutely. Peer review shouldn't just be a gateway it should be a formative constructive process. Especially for early career researchers it's really critical that they get, the publishers actually tells the peer reviewer - please be constructive and helpful. You may not recommend publication but you may tell the person - this is what you need to do to develop the structure of your work and so forth. It's been really helpful for me.
QUESTION: So what in the process from your perspective, it probably would apply to others as well, during that process you were annoyed about having to wait and annoyed about things not being accessible necessarily depending on where they end up at the end of that process but it is important for the method that you describe that your work gets peer reviewed and properly checked by your community and that in itself involves them being able to access the information. When you're writing something and publishing it and putting it through that process, what kind of value do you get back not from where your publishing or what it costs but from the actual doing of here's my work, somebody with skills reads it and then gives it back to you. Do you find that helps you learn and improve your work?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes. Sometimes it's also been absolutely insanely wrong but that's because some of my work is quite political and so someone may not share my politics necessarily.
QUESTION: So you find the feedback that you received through that process really valuable?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: That's a good idea. At Ubiquity we are working a lot on peer review. But it's very subject specific. So in archeology people aren't quite as open to that yet maybe it's another generation of students away. People are still quite concerned about their comments being open and openly available as reviewers. I think for the authors maybe it's not quite as much of a thing. But in other areas like medicine and psychology and so forth it's almost becoming a requirement. So the psychology journals we have, people are asking - can you make things open? So it's very important for the validation process as well not just for improving your work which is critical because i think if you know that the early stages of your work will be available and you know that the comments and the reworking will be available as well then it actually makes you work better right throughout the process and concentrate on the quality and things. The rest of the time i think people are thinking about quickly getting the work out and they will address the reviews comments in a minimal way just to get things done more quickly but if things are open they will actually engage and try produce a more community built project product. So i think in the longer term open review and even open authoring will produce much much higher quality work
QUESTION: Do you think given that the peer review process itself debate can come up around the work for all kinds of reasons, say like the politics that you just mentioned would it be worthwhile for you for that kind of information itself and that debate to be something people can access or not?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes I've done quite a lot.
QUESTION: Have you done any peer reviewing yourself?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I'd be absolutely fine with that
QUESTION: How do you feel about the comments you make on peer review being made public?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: It hasn't happened yet
QUESTION: Are you ever concerned that...?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I don't think that it would be detrimental to me because i would i would basically be fulfilling my social contract to take part in reviewing and so forth and it would force me to make sure that what i was saying was fair and to make sure that any assertion i made was backed up by some sort of fact. So in that case I'm contributing. I don't think I'm doing anything negative.
QUESTION: Are you concerned that if you said something negative about a colleagues work that that would be detrimental to you in some way? Would the fact that it was detrimental to you stop you from doing it?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Well with us specifically there have been quite, the things we started doing first of all was publishing in open access in humanities and social sciences. One of the things we did there was we came up with a very low cost model because funds are tighter in humanities and social sciences and people aren't used to having to arrange for their funder to pay in so forth in their institutions. So we came up with as low a cost model as we could and that was successful in humanities so we validated that and that's what we built the whole company on. Even if it's a science journal we charge about 10%of what others do tops. We think it's fair and it makes us sustainable but it also shows them that the money is not being wasted so it also builds trust with the research community that open access is actually probably the fairest way of charging for publishing. So we also make our financial model completely transparent and we publish every line of what an article processing charge goes towards. So that's about trying to change peoples attitudes to open access and that it's not a money making scheme and it's all being done in their interests and then what we started looking was making sure that it's not just the articles themselves being published but it's also the data and software associated with them.So we link up to the institutions repositories and other data repositories through our data journals and we allow people to write a short paper about the data and to gain credit for it that way and so we put a platform of journals across a range of different subjects and we are trying to first of all encourage people in those communities to publish data and also software in the software journal and that's really starting to pick up steam. People are getting the idea and there starting to cite these papers. We had a paper go forward for a ref. for someone who their main output was data they didn't write papers or journal articles so they had to have something that could be refd on the data paper and that's working well. What we are going to start doing is investigating can we help people to search across that platform and start to identify data that they can use for cross disciplinary work and that kind of thing. We are extending that out we are adding access to data repositories say for every single journal a mandatory thing for people who submit, unless they have a good reason they should make that data available as well. That's what we've done we've built a platform where we're starting to integrate data and software publication along side normal articles and the same thing with books basically. What we have really decided is that we don't feel, we got involved because we wanted to encourage open scholarship and we didn't feel a lot of the other publishers were doing that well and we still don't feel that there is much of a change happening among the big legacy publishers. So what we want to do now is we want to accelerate things and we want to re situate as much publishing as possible back to the research community and we want to be a catalyst for that. So what we're doing is we're making our platform available on a re rendered basis to universities to run their own presses and so we have a bunch of universities signing up at the moment. This is something we really only began six months ago and we are going to build a network of university presses running on our infrastructure. So we run the back end for the university and they run the front office, the sales and the interface with the researchers. Bit it de-risks the whole operation of running a university press for them. It makes it very easy to get setup. Everything's being run for them in terms of infrastructure and development and type setting and things like that. So universities like to have the prestige of their own press but they also need an alternative to the big publishers. Right now they have their RCUK funds where they have all this money for open access publishing and it's being siphoned off at an alarming rate by £3,000 per APC. So we want to offer them the ability to create their own publishing operation at 10% of the cost of that and to use those funds more efficiently more in the interests of researchers. So that's kind of the bigger picture that's evolving this year. Which is building this network of university presses which support one another and can start developing more open scholarship based approaches so then each university would have it's own data journal, software journal, they'll share peer reviewers across the universities so the peer review process can run more efficiently and we are looking at things like returning part of the APC to the department of the person who does the peer review. So that the people see that they are being rewarded for what they do and the university is getting some fair value and what we then do is we really start to bring in is university presses from the developing world. I'm working with the university of Nairobi and helping them with their press. We are starting to talk to Chinese universities about whether they can become involved in the network and that then gives them the advantage of running a press to western standards so they get some acknowledgement for the quality of their work and the concerns are addressed about, often people assume that all Chinese workers are either non peer reviewed or plagiarised or so forth which in big universities isn't the case but by operating a western sub press with accreditation they can really address those concerns. They can be involved in a network, it's a way of integrating people in those parts of the world with people publishing in other parts of the world.
QUESTION: OK so we'll change topic slightly. You mentioned your work, your PhD and Ubiquity Press and getting that going. When you do your work you make your data available so people can use that so how in the more recent sense of not what you've been doing as an academic throughout your life but right now in the last few years say, what changes and what new practiced have you picked up, what interesting things have been going on in Ubiquity Press and with similar organizations in the area?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: They are a little bit. Overall things like the Finch report and so forth were positive because they were a step in the direction and they involved a mandate which involved saying change is going to happen. The way we work is we are both gold and green. So we are a gold publisher - we charge for what we do but we make things fully open access but we also believe in the green side of things. The archiving side and we automatically archive to repositories. We actually encourage researchers to post their papers and so forth. That side of it to us is kind of a moot thing if you're from an open access publisher you're not going to limit the green side of things so it's more a case of a lot of the people who were on the Finch report or the publishers that were interviewed said - if we charge less than £2,000 we'll go bankrupt. We won't be able to do this. They only interviewed largely legacy publishers and when we later on showed our model to people who had been on the committee they were very surprised. I have shown it to government ministers and so forth and they've said but no-one told me it was possible to do this.
QUESTION: So you mentioned there that you want to show people that open access isn't a money making thing and you mentioned the article processing charges so how does that tie in with the recent sort of government reviews that have come out which have promoted certain kinds of open access?. Do you feel that they are in some way making it sound like it's a money making exercise?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: It's also that, research money is critical to science. We have a limited pool of it and we have to make the best possible use of it and that is in the interest of all of society and if it's being wasted especially for private company profits that's quite scandalous. So part of what we want to do by A having a lower processing charge and B making that transparent is we want to help drive costs down across the industry. So it's not just about us grabbing a big market share and becoming successful it's also about trying to change the way the other companies are working. So hopefully researchers will have a choice on where to publish and they'll be able to make that decision partly based on whether they thing the money is being spent wisely.
QUESTION: So that has quite a relevant impact in the fact that you're setting up a company here to do this kind of thing there's essentially, there's the reason any new company sets up which is that there is an entrenched collection of people providing a service but the cost is high and in some way you can provide perhaps a better service for a smaller cost
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Potentially, I'm not sure. I'm not sure there is a quality issue. I think there's been some misinformation spread by some parties so some of the larger publishers have told their research community that they'll have to stop publishing the journals if things go to open access because they won't be able to sustain the costs which i don't think is correct. That's happened in Humanities a little bit. They've spread misinformation about the licensing and things like that saying if we use open access licensing your work is more likely to be plagiarised and all this sort of thing which isn't true. So some of the quality concerns are being whipped up a little bit by the lobby it's from publishers who know that open access and the APC model is going to happen no matter what but they are trying to stall it as long as they can because they are making big profits in subscriptions. So i think a lot of the concerns about quality are temporary and as more and more of the industry shift across people and younger generations who are convinced by the principles of open access, they won't pay so much attention to that.
QUESTION: So there's a bit of a dichotomy between sticking with the older traditions at a higher cost than is now possible and kind of moving to newer models so that we can be more efficient with the funds available. Not even just the funds but the resources available to do scholarship. But this is requiring some sort of transition at least which is making people uncomfortable perhaps with the quality issues.
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I think if you do that it's in your own interest you must try and publish every research article you've got and if you're publishing study, you need to publish the data, you need to publish the software you've used. You need to make it available and it's not just for validation it's because people will actually take your work and they will expand upon it and you won't just get more citations and so forth but you'll build research connections around the world and you'' become involved in collaborative projects and increase your own career prospects because people have actually taken the data you've used and worked with it. So all the studies showing that you get enhanced, increased interaction if you publish the data as well as the paper. You'll get more readers and so forth. What we're finding with the software is possible there is even more, a greater potential there because people can save a lot of time reusing research software. Once again that leads to more interaction and so forth. So if you're publishing with any publisher you should really insist upon the fact that not just your article comes out with an open license so that you have a proper impact, but that they are willing to take the data and the software as well. Or you archive it somewhere and you insist that they allow you to cite it properly and a lot of publishers at the moment won't take data citations and they won't really, there are issues with it - with even where to cite software on a paper and so forth. I think that in this community we need to develop some standards around how we cite software and data as well. So our approach here has been that we have created data and software journals, where in order to get the paper in the journal you have to archive the software or the data professionally and you link it from the paper so that it's persistently available but then you cite those papers in your other articles or books and they will go straight into the reference list they don't get stripped out or argued about with the publisher. So we have set those up so there is always a place where you can publish the data and software and reference it in other works.
QUESTION: Thinking of what comes next then - the younger generations and so on, researchers and so on, as they move into this field say completing their PhD's or even earlier works than that they come to publish and so much more of what they've done will rely in some way on software or data even in the humanities there's a lot now of humanities work that rellys on an analysis of say conversations that happened and digital social media and so on. If they were to come along and need to make that available, what would you say they should do? Should they come to Ubiquity Press with certain types of material or you don't need to focus on your own company if you don't feel comfortable but how would you recommend someone in the younger generation who has some data, some software and they've got some analysis of that that they want to publish as a - here's my article, my story about my research and here's the supporting data, as you described yourself like you have your own supporting data and making that available helps people validate the work.
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes especially. Especially from people who's predominant output is data or software. So if you work in a university in research stuff where you are possibly classed as a technician although what you actually do is high class research work. You are working on very complicated alga rhythms to process scientific information but the fact that you have X number of Git hub projects and it's been several times over by the projects doesn't really count, doesn't count for the ref and things like that. That's where we've tried to use the journals as a way of saying - well in this case you've got X number of downloads and citations on a paper so it acts as a proxy for what you've done that other people in the research community will understand. It's definitely lacking.
QUESTION: So as a creator of data and software in my work. One of the things I've experienced i guess is that it's very, very easy to create software and share it and collaborate and to have people using it and to essentially be cited for the software i use in the software development community at least. Do you think that there's a certain amount of that that's lacking from the scholarly community?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes i think it's critical. Hopefully in the future i think things will start to become merged. Data and so forth will become something you can access directly from a publication more easily. That kind of thing. We don't quite know yet how people are going to interact with the article of the future. It could be that we find ways to cite data more effectively within those articles and so forth. Right now people use reference lists and they use DOI's and that;s the only thing they understand and our ways of measuring impact, the metrics we use all depend in that. I think that for the next three to five years that's what we'll focus on . Beyond that will be very interesting, whether the paper becomes more of a package of things which is published to slightly different platforms to what we see in the journal today. I think that's possible where we're heading but it's a bit of a grey area. We need lots of experimentation in that area. We would love for people to come to us and publish experimental journals which would work like that. So we are starting to do things like include code into our articles and video and things like that. But it's still very much shackled by the traditional model. So the idea of publishing a large research subject that contained everything and could be interrogated in different ways would be interesting.
QUESTION: So looking forward then, is the combination of that kind of approach, being able to cite and reference more useful materials quite important to what you hope will happen in the future with Ubiquity Press and with others?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes, i think so . I think we need a lot more of that. The universities should be doing a lot more exploratory work in that area. Obviously as publishers we don't have a lot of time to spend on that at the moment.
QUESTION: So there seems to be a layer of research going on on top of research then? Researching new ways to publish research?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: I think it helps it. I don't see a commercial company operating by itself is going to be able to build the future. I think it has to come from the researchers themselves. This is about research communication. So it needs to be scientists and researchers actually building these systems themselves or imputing into them and driving them. Otherwise it's not going to serve that community. So that's partly where we hoped that by building the university presses up and helping them to regain a major share of publishing we can keep them close to the research community and we can start to do more experimental things with them.
QUESTION: So you just said that universities should spend a lot more time on that? What about the fact then that you're spending time on it but you're not at university, is there something helping you there where actually this kind of work now is going on beyond the boundaries of what used to be considered scholarly institutions. Does it all need to go back into what was a scholarly institution, or is it possible to spread it out?
NAME: Brian

ANSWER: Yes so that's where we really believe that the publishing belongs much, much closer to the university. It's just that we have to help the university to mitigate a lot of the risks involved with running a company and developing software and so forth. If we can take care of all of the standard publishing part of it and free them up to design it, innovate publications and so forth. Then maybe some really interesting things will come out of it
QUESTION: So it's coming back to what you mentioned at the beginning, originally where you worked at the start there wasn't enough of a connection with that community to generate the tools that were required?

It should be about producing knowledge, that's what it's about.
