ANSWER: My current role is research community manager within University of Melbourne.But previous to this I've spent the past 5 years working for funding agencies. So the joint information systems committee in the UK and i worked for the Australian National Data Service in Australia and actually. I am currently working with the National Research cloud project Nectar which is still partly mine. So i continue to play a role within the funding Agency, so naturally the kind of mandates and the stuff you put on research whether that's open access or open tools for the research cloud, or open data with the Australian National data service, Basically in each one of the roles I've had as a funding agency, open has played in trying to make those decisions and most importantly trying to justify those decisions.
NAME: David

ANSWER: Sure. I guess for me other than the broad sweeping arguments of, you can hear my accent I'm American so even though i have British citizenship and I'm applying for Australian citizenship. I've always been very sensitive to the fact that in spending tax payer money whether it be in the US, UK or Australia, that's what you're doing right and it's scary to look at someone who pays taxes and say - i'm spending your money and yet i don't have the same accent as you or the same ideals of user patriotism as you. That type of thing, so that's always mattered to me, to be defending that at a very real level. Now that's nice as a broad sweeping argument, but the moment you get into the long tailed discussion of kind of opening up something like bio-medical data or something and you get into a conversation about anonomizing it or de-identifying it, there's a very long tailed discussion that has to occur in each one of the different disciplines and all the rest of it. For better or worse i feel that it does basically improve the rate and the speed of which scholarship occurs. If you can get the problems out of the way, if we can come up with a good de-identification or way of anonymizing the data, or tools or whatever, in a way that it can be made open then i actually feel that what that will do for researchers is that it will get them more research funding and save them time. So it comes down to a very real thing where researchers actually can say - because i opened up my data and put in that extra effort to anonymize it and now it's out there in the open, then said researcher across the country, the globe and I've seen this, I've friends, i'm much more closer to. People talk about international like they know what it it is, I've seen it. I've got a meta researcher in Oxford who's worked with a researcher in Melbourne who I've then connected to a researcher, you know who's in Sandeago and that's very real. It's a very small group but then they do really amazing and cool things. Most of the time it's the data, the tools, the method or the publication that's enabled them to participate and do things with that. So it isn't even about open. The word i use more than anything else is collaborative. Open enables collaboration. Open is not a means to an end, collaboration is where we want to get researchers doing things and that involves all the problems of human psychology, of trust, of relationships and all the rest of it. But open is at least one pillar inside it being able to accelerate that place where we can collaborate that.
QUESTION: So what has been the main impact of the open versus closed debate for you? Have you always very much been on this side of getting funding out for people that are or aren't doing open or has it impacted? Did it impact you personally trying to access materials or publish materials?
NAME: David

ANSWER: Sure. I guess the communities I've experienced, and the reason i'm so. I want other people to see the open source community and the developers community. It's the community to me that exemplifies or typifies what can be achieved when people start to work in the open and allow things to be shared quickly and all the rest of it. I mean, the Linux community, the MIAS QL community. My problem with my first experience with openness war round my MIAS QL. This massive database could be used anywhere, i could write in MIAS QL. I was a database developer in a very previous life and as a young person out of under grad who was doing database management that would have been my first experience and then you tend to look up and outside it wasn't just MIAS QL there was all these other things happening. My career has actually allotted to 15 years of for being a database developer. You just realise how amazing it is with all the opens that are out there. I love open hardware right now, reprinting and sharing all of that stuff is amazing but there is another hundred of those opens that all provide that same thing. All that by opening up what they're doing, they create more collaboration and they do what humans want to do which is socialise, share things, trust one another to produce better things that actually we can't do as individuals anymore and we have to do it in group scenarios in group things.
QUESTION: n the past, was there a clear time where this distinction started to emerge? Where you started to realise that there was a requirement to make it clear that people should share, or that they could share? Was there a distinct shift during the time you were working where suddenly people were more or less interested in how things actually got diseminated or accessed or has it always been the case that where you worked at least you've been trying to get people to collaborate, regardless of
NAME: David

ANSWER: I'm glad to talk about obviously the research cloud. That's the open stack and that's enabled to allow people to work on things together. I can talk about that. I could also talk about the community aspects building of that. For me what's really amazing is that i actually don't believe you can have community unless you have open. Open builds trust. Trust builds community. So are either of those you'd be interested in?
QUESTION: What then more recently have you been working on, or are you working on at the moment where these working practices are typified? How does that benefit people now? You might find that you are connecting people up and they are getting collaboration and so what sort of outputs are you seeing from that kind of work?
NAME: David

ANSWER: So i think the thing that I'm most passionate about and care about right now is the research cloud and so we're using a piece of technology called Open Stac which is a bit like Amazon web services. But the cool thing about it is again isn't the technology, it's the fact that it allows us to openly share things. One of my favourite examples is what i call the ball of clay example, which is, normally people have got Tab software, 3-D software and the problem with that is that you're doing it by yourself. It's like you standing over a ball of clay and doing the whole thing together so it's cut scene and now imagine ghost and there's a ball of clay between the two of us. Being able to both put our hands on that and form it together, that's the amazing possibility of collaboration. So it took an open piece of technology to enable that, researcher doesn't even know it's called open stac, they ust know that they now have this share of a piece of software that they're using sitting on the cloud and it enables them to be both looking at this thing with one another and it's interesting as open stac is now open, but the software we're using isn't necessarily open. But it's enough open that it's enabled the collaboration in the community and that's what's exciting, because once you have two people using that, all of a sudden the ability to scale out and bring more and more people into the all of clay problem and that's what's cool. Unlike the physical enironment wher you can only maybe fit six hands on the ball of clay, in the digital space there is an upward number.
QUESTION: The community aspects i guess, but if it related to being a community around a technology then a bit of that but not the technical details.
NAME: David

ANSWER: It literally is the opportunity to collaborate. The whole point is that researchers feel alone and isolated in using their tools. I mean we did a tool audit of researchers at the Uni of Melbourne and we think, it's a very broad structure, back of a napkin time numbers right. Each department, five or six research tools, N number of departments times N number of international collaborations, subdivided by some core tools that people use. So we think it's like two hundred to five hundred tools sit on any given research canvas. Which isn't all that shocking really, i think that's pretty normal. But the point of that is that you do feel really alone in these tools. So a linguist doing tree maps will have these really niche bits of software which are really cool and powerful for them but they are actually quite old and one of the most difficult things is that they eventually get the thing up and working but then you're like well how do i do this? So the ability to turn around and ask somebody how to do that is really powerful and the other interesting side to that coin is, this is something I'm very passionate about, is you're never going to provide a help desk for that. That's one of the problems. IT, the traditional solution has been - here is a tool, let's provide a help desk. Hi i'm the researcher, I'm working on Indonesian languages from the sixth period such and such and i want to produce a tree diagram which works with this language and bridges to this language. That's impossible, We are never going to get a help desk for that type of thing. The only solution in this is community and collaboration, ergo back to my original point. If you don't have open, that's the other point, it enables more open. The diconomy of us buying a bunch of software to make it open. So we buy a site license that now allows us to use a piece of software so that it feels open to everybody on the campus. But the sad part is that that is kind of limiting because what we actually want to do is to make sure that our researcher working with the African researcher, with the Indian researcher or the Chinese researcher also has access to that tool and all of a sudden we are getting problems when in fact, they would much rather Skye their colleagues in Indian than necessarily turn around and ask someone round the corner?
QUESTION: So you mentioned there that another researcher doesn't know that it's called open stac or depending on the research you may not be aware of the software or any of the technology going on behind it. So what is it that you think is helping you to engage with researchers then to bring them into that, what particular aspect is it that makes them get engaged with what you're providing? Makes them change their mind or join this collaboration?
NAME: David

ANSWER: That's my obsession. Community building is everything for me because it's not a science, it's definitely an art. It would depend on which discipline as well. For example the linguist. We have been working with them to produce a mapping application so that you can imagine all the languages, all the different aboriginal languages across Australia and how those overlap and their relationship on a big map. So we have been using a nice piece of software called all open source on the open sector. People can use it with one another. Thus far the way we've been doing that is, again this goes back to the developer community giving them a list serve, giving them some tags to be able to talk about on whether that's Google plus, twitter or face book and then encouraging face to face. So we do have a really big advantage i that we are on a campus in the Uni of Melbourne. We are not distributed. So for us the technology tools - list ser, the twitter, all of that is actually a function of getting people together face to face because again it's hierarchy right. You get open, I've got to get trust and you're not usually going to get trust by someone tweeting one or another. So usually the fastest way to get trust is to have a face to face conversation and then all of a sudden the tools start to enable this collaboration. But we've got to build trust and i'm not saying you can't do trustified tools and e-mails or something or maybe Skye or whatever. But for me the fastest way we have always been able to achieve that is by face to face. Get the people together, get the linguist talking with other art historians. They all of a sudden are willing to e-mail each other and trust and it's not necessarily like the list serve right, they would rather e-mail me and then have a quite conversation on the side than put it out on the list serve. Researchers are inherently private people.
QUESTION: Are you seeing examples of where that sort of support is starting to build up within the communities? Where a particular researcher with a problem can go and ask for help, where might they do that?
NAME: David

ANSWER: Well, that's interesting. I don't know if we've gone that far yet. I think over the next eighteen months I'll be able to answer that question. What we're trying is really new. I mean most IT departments in universities are very very comfortable with help desks now and to propose that instead you are going to you this hippie free wheeling mechanism to do self supporting networks, it feels more like alcoholics anonymous than it feels like an official enterprise IT support department and yet I'm open for other discussions. Although saying that, what i do find interesting is that the open technology allows us to carry that on. One of the cool things is that by utilising the cloud and by utilising open stac, means that when a researcher comes along and uses a tool, at least that tool is still there. So there is a chance for further collaborations to occur beyond the life of the one person using it. In the old days it would have been - I've uploaded the tool, i have a ton of mail on my desk top my laptop either gets tossed or out the window. So we've then lost that persons project, their tool and most importantly we've lost the persons knowledge. I can't say the persons knowledge, they've moved on and that's the whole goal. But if we can save their tool and their data and get them to sign off on something at the end of their time here with us saying - i don't mind if you keep this data and this tool. That's a lot easier than us going and saying - can i have the stuff off your laptop. If it's already sitting in out network, secure and controlled but then we later go along and say, hey we've got this tool and another post graduate wants to use your tool that you built or the modifications then we're hoping that's the outcome. But again, ask me in eighteen months and I'll have a better idea.
QUESTION: So we are moving forwards from these collaborations that you are helping people with the tools that you're providing. What happens beyond those, when those are finished and people come to compete the work they've used these systems to build, are they quite happy and comfortable, are all their issued solved or does this new collaborative working style bring up more problems that you have to deal with when it comes to completing a piece of work?
NAME: David

ANSWER: To tell you the truth I'm fairly optimistic about it. Just because i have built ambassador champion programmes before so i know what it means to have to get your ambassadors and champions and incentivize them, how to deal with the fact that when you loose them, how to role out new ones and all the rest of it. Community building i am pretty comfortable with. What will be really interesting is how well we can do with, the best part is Post Graduates are absolutely the best group of people you can have for ambassadors and champions - incredibly smart, not a lot of money so motivating them isn't incredibly hard, really altruistic. Most post graduates inertly care about and are open right and into doing things new. They're not like old professors and there's a lot of them. In the university of Melbourne there's twenty five thousand of them who have taught and researched there so i think we have a really large pool of people and basically for some pizza money and maybe sending them to a conference every now and again. I've got myself, for the cost of one salary member, i reckon i could have twenty five post graduate champions each representing the different areas for the same cost. It's maybe me playing a little bit fast and loose but why not utilise volunteer organisational structures where this is borrowed from. Me understanding the national society and they way to do community building with the open knowledge foundation. Those skills all come together and we are utilising just a different structure than the help desk. We are utilising the community structure and it's a valid structure. It really does work and most importantly if you don't believe me go and look in any of thee big open source communities. They scale to potentially millions. So in theory it should be easy.
QUESTION: So do you think your focus for the next eighteen months will be trying to communicate to people how they can do these things differently and how they can get them, it sounds like you're saying - these tools are there and the open source stuff is there and you can make them available but it's changing the way people have worked in the past. You're having to change the structure of the help desk and so on, so is that going to be quite a challenge?
NAME: David

ANSWER: The main dilemma, is my worry - i think we're in a place of, there's the typical model of storming, forming, norming and over the past ten years i think we've been in the state of storming. There have been all these tools created for researchers to do different things but now we're starting to have the forming stage where finally people are starting to centre around certain very specific tools and it's tools like map lab and R stat and svss and stata and excel obviously. But there are starting to become some coalescence inside of these. Now what i find really interesting, is that the cats software we're using is going to become really core research software that people use. My question is will that be, and I'm back and forth on that a lot, like i said, what i care about is not that the tools open. I care that it has the largest possibility to have the largest community group because i can't support that tool myself. I can't have a help desk. I need that community whether that be the university of Melbourne community or even better a world wide community to say - we all support R stat as a statistical programming tool to be able to do all of our graphs inside of our research papers. My worry with that is that, R stat is great because it is a world wide community where as something like map lab costs a lot of money to do. So it's very privileged and university of Melbourne is the number one research uni in Australia and obviously can afford that and it needs a lot of money to do those things. We have a very large budget for buying research tools but i don't know that that's the best thing for research as a whole and Australia know this. The number of Chinese universities coming on line and even coming into the top one hundred universities. Even Africa's going up. Those groups could disruptabley innovate the whole thing and switch the thing around because they will be using a different tool and they will be over here. So i really believe it's important that we have to figure out a way to keep people in open tools and again, it's not because it's open it's because my researchers will have the best opportunities to find people to trust and collaborate with around the world because again, research is niche. It's really difficult to find someone who does know the Latin for this period and this region. There are only going to be two or three other people on the planet legitimately and if that persons using R Stat and the other persons using Map Lab they won't work with one another. They might have a conversation but the moment they have a tool they can work with one another, they are solving a problem with one another and that's what brings people together and that's what builds trust. It needs to be a shared tool and so some disciplines might decide that mathmatica is the tool that all mathematicians need to use and fair enough. As long as that's defacto.
QUESTION: So let's say you're going to solve that problem and everyone will be happy. What else then in the eighteen months or longer term, what's coming up for you that's a big issue. What will you need to solve later on or what will stop you doing the things you had hoped to achieve or what is coming up that will make things better for your work?
NAME: David

ANSWER: I think that's the most important tool of all. Basically the process of writing things with one another is essential and so word is crap for that. Anyone who has ever passed around revisions and I'm talking pure features whether it's open or closed. But the problem with word is that it's legitimately a bad technology for collaborating because passing reviews around means they are all out of sync and somebodies got to bring them back together. I really love google docs. If i said a preference right now, i would say google docs. For the most part at least it's free to use so there's not a barrier there, people can collaborate. But again the problem with Google docs is that it can lead to imbed the science and the data inside of it. You can do it to some degree and this is the point - once you start to collaborate and write a document with one another that's one thing. It's another thing once you start to do experiments and you need to pull the experiments inside of the research to do that. You have your experiment there and them most importantly once your experiments inside of that, what do you do? You then go out to your peer review and you get critiques about why everything is wrong. So then you're in a place again, just like the word document with reviews and it's oh shit we have to change all the graphs in this paper so that they line up with all the formulas along with all the tables and actually google docs. starts to fail there as well and then you move onto the next step. This is what i find really interesting is again back to the developer community, the developers are the ones who are dealing in this ultra collaborative space. They've invented tools like Latex and Mark Down and that's what i would see as the future as they are being able to write something and collaborate on it all at the same time like google docs. and then have peer review come in to it. Look at the data, change it. allow errors and ultimate revisions and then have versions all the way back. From inception of one author, to six authors writing it together to the editorials looking at it, to peer review giving comments back to it, to re-editing it. Thats' the whole chain that needs to be there. Not that any one's going to look at it but it should be there.
QUESTION: I want to bring something out of what you just said there. Explaining how you want to focus on tools out there and how having those tools openly available for the bigger community and you also mentioned that people will obviously publish their research when they are finished. So publication of research in itself is a tool, for communicating information. So what do you think about that tool in particular is that something that you can see as being a way of getting people to collaborate and be open with each other?
NAME: David

ANSWER: You publish it.
QUESTION: So what happens at the end, does anyone look at it? You collaborate, you create this object, this artifact that has all your story, your back story as well. People can if they want to, search it and find out what you've done but then what do you do with it?
NAME: David

ANSWER: On the web. It's already out there. I think publish is a bad word. We need a new word that shouldn't be publish, it should be..... In all those versions they are all being published essentially but slowly released to different audiences and I'd even make the argument that, I've been doing this with a report recently, my peer reviewers are actually my target audience. They are the people i want to read the paper. So i will pretend in a way, that i am giving them exclusive access as you as an expert need to read this. I'm not doing it I'm actually hand delivering it. My editorial process is handing it to the main people i want to read the thing. The publication process where i hand it out and give it to the world it's kind of a long tail argument where i don't really care because my beta reviewers, my peer reviewers were actually the group that i wanted to read this thing. The rest of the world, i don't really care. It's the group of people that participated in that. So it's non consequential whether or not it does need to be opened up. It does need to be opened up because I'm invited to go and speak at conferences afterwards because people find that on the web and that's great for me because it brings up the next research. It's not publish, it's ........
QUESTION: Where does that happen?
NAME: David

ANSWER: Absolutely
QUESTION: So you have an advantage gained fro the information being opening that other people find it and ask you to come and talk. So in the same where you were describing how you help people collaborate at your university. Do you find the same benefits for yourself
NAME: David

ANSWER: I eat my own dog food on this stuff. That's the nice thing about advocating this, is it's valuable to write research type stuff papers and there's a lot to be said for the scholarly method. I don't really know, I've never really published in nature and what happens when you have one hundred thousand people ask you a question because you have invented an idea. I have no idea about that. But what i do know, as a minor researcher in my own field is that it's a lot more advantageous for me to be out there than in some little shitty journal that i think people don't care about. The nice bit, again going back to the post graduates, that's what the post graduates are - post graduates are early career researchers. That are learning to do it that way and the whole point is that these post graduate researchers aren't going to be an Einstein or a Dawkins. It's just not going to happen. They're going to be minor researchers their entire life and they are going to have to fight and struggle to get research publications and frankly having a blog and pushing your ideas out there and doing revisions openly and utilising these tool chains. That gives you what is seen as being busy in the space, which builds up trust which gives you the next research grant. So we suffer in academia extremely about fame. Most researchers think - I'm secretly going to be the next Einstein. You're not, statistically you're not. You know this and you should know better than most because you actually have the mathematical skills but that's the point. It's actually about a better way of working if you want to get more money and do what you want to do. Working in the open makes you seem valuable to the community because you seem busy in the open.

ANSWER: Well we are trying to control mosquito populations because a small proportion of mosquito species transmit human disease. Which in the case of Malaria for instance, is one of the worlds biggest killers. The mosquito's that i work on transmit virus which is one of the most prevalent viruses. It doesn't kill as many people as Malaria does, but it does put a lot of people at risk and there are millions of infections every year which will give people two or three weeks off work and it's very unpleasant. There is no cure, there is no vaccine. So our only methods at the moment of controlling the spread of that disease is based on mosquito's and so that's why it's important to find new methods particularly as our use chemicals but mosquito's develop resistance to those and have been doing for quite a long time. So we are looking for biological methods of control. In my case either using bacteria that infects mosquito's and is transmitted mother to daughter and then my second placement will be working on making mosquito's genetically sterile. So that you can at least repress the population that way. So there's a double approach. Population placement, so this bacteria method produces mosquito's that can't transmit the deadly virus and the idea is to replace the natural population with bacterial infected mosquito's. Or there is population suppression which is reducing the absolute numbers by using the sterile effects. So that's the idea.
QUESTION: Do you give a simple explanation, so that people will understand who are not in your area of work, why you are controlling mosquito populations and what you are trying to achieve with this?
NAME: Jenny

ANSWER: So a mixture of things. Some techniques have been passed from post docs to me. Both written and in terms of demonstrated to me. Especially specialist techniques for this this lab. So we do mosquito micro injections which uses a specialist bit of kit which not every lab would have. Some of the more basic stuff i picked up during practicals as an undergraduate and kind of doing research projects as part of my earlier degree. Obviously in practicals it is demonstrated to you as part of the undergraduate learning process and again demonstrations, the kind of written instructions handed out during research projects. But there have been quite a few occasions where I've been using methods or tests that no-one in the lab has done before. So in that case i get my information from the published literature. Usually as my first port of call because i realise that anyone in the lab group who has done an essay or realise i want to do an essay will find it. But that then generally doesn't contain enough information for me to actually do the essay so beyond that, if it's a manufacturers kit, I'll get the manufacturers instructions. If it isn't a kit, I'll just try and dig back through the literature to try and find the original methods paper or at least the first paper to use that method as that tends to be a lot more detailed than later written out instructions. That's basically the way it goes. But i do find that if I'm doing that it will never work the first time or probably the second time because there's always something that you just don't know learn without doing it and realising that you need to put in another step or that for your samples this isn't going to work. So it's a mixture of for certain techniques there will be someone there who knows and will pass it on or there are very clear and detailed written instructions that is usually shared just between the lab. Although i have downloaded lab protocols from other labs. Which are non published just stuff that they share on their websites. Which are very helpful as they are very minutely detailed and then beyond that it's digging back into the literature. Often having to read many papers just to try and piece together steps that another paper left out and then cross referencing that to the manufacturers instructions. So it's a mixture.
QUESTION: So now we have an idea of what you do and why you're doing it. Could we talk about, i guess there is a history ocurrent and a future type approach to this. NAME: Jenny

QUESTION: Is it more often the case that you find those by going and searching for them on google, rather than, do you often need to ask someone specifically for a given type of that material, or does someone come to you and say - by the way use x?
NAME: Jenny

ANSWER: Yes, it's usually a mixture. I don't really mind where it comes from as long as it's detailed enough that i can try and do it myself. But often it will be a case of mashing things together because you'll often be using different kinds of samples to, they might have done it in a cell line and you'll have to get a whole mosquito and you'll have to go back and think well how can i do this. Often you'll just have make some of it up and hope that it works. So there is an element of not being able to find it but i do try and get as much covered as possible. But for journal articles, they do tend to miss out quite a lot of crucial information. For instance, solvents. I had about ten tabs open with different journal articles trying to find out what they dissolved this compound in which i knew couldn't be dissolved in water, at the concentration they said they had used it at but no where did they say that they had dissolved in this DMSO which is the solvent i found out about on the tenth or eleventh paper that they specifically said. Which is unfortunate because you don't know that they have properly controlled by just putting the solvent in the other cell lines that weren't treated. So there's a lot of that, the small details that i guess because it;s their research community they feel don't need to be stated and that everyone should know that your solvent is DMSO. But i do find that if you're going outside your own local research community which in our research community we do a lot because a lot of the effects of the bacteria we study have only really been discovered in the last, well since 2008. So a lot of the time the stuff that you're wanting to apply to the problems that we have are not native techniques to this particular research area and you have to delve into other areas where i definitely think there is an assumed knowledge that i don't have, and no-one else in the lab has so yes you do end up with those sorts of situations.
QUESTION: So when you're doing that kind of googling are you specifically looking for materials that are outside the journal articles or are you in a combined effort so you are searching for things that may be in articles that may be on manufacturers websites, that may be on your peers websites?

ANSWER: I think in that case because so many papers hadn't mentioned it that that was just the assumption that everyone must know that you put this stuff in because in that particular research community i think it's a pretty standardry agent. So they just assumed everyone knew. There were other cases where I've tried to replicate something and I've realise that they've not written about an entire centrifugation step and then i have thought - it's quite a big thing to leave out. I'm not sure that it was trying to not allow other people to replicate it but they certainly must have realised that it would make it a lot harder to replicate if they didn't write down that they had done that in the interim. Especially when you are using expensive regents and you are using consumables. It's really frustrating because then you realise you've got it all written down from the method in the paper and then you realise that you have got two steps ahead of yourself because there was clearly something you should have done in the middle and now you've blocked all your filters and now there's nothing you can do so yes i think there are definitely times but it's difficult to check to know the intention in what people are writing.

ANSWER: I haven't published any papers yet for research. I would definitely try and write some where critical in as clearly and in as detailed manner as possible. Which is possible. I see papers where it's very clearly written out and I'm pretty confident that all the steps are in there. So i guess i would foresee anything extra going in as supplementary materials and more detailed methods if necessary. If it won't fit in the paper word count. Which is quite handy, i see a few labs doing that. They'll just put everything as a supplementary file that won't fit in and then and at least it's available. I guess most of the, in terms of methodology stuff works quite nicely. In terms of the data, the output is usually a graph. For instance a lot of my work is on gene expression. In which case it will just be a graph of gene expression or relative gene expression in certain samples. ANSWER: I think I'm putting all this effort in to doing the work. I'd rather that people benefited from it as much as possible. The work that I'm doing here doesn't have any commercial value as such. I'm not expecting to make any money out of it and i don't think anyone else really is. So it's more about furthering knowledge and letting people do what they want with it. It's more that prior to the publication they wouldn't want it, just in case it has to get written up in a patent. So i don't particularly think, under the current IP system that just has to be the way it is for most companies. I would have a problem i think if they were very strong about the rest of my thesis not being available. The official embargo for the company is five years which i think is a long time, i suppose it takes a while to get things pateneted but if they were insistent that the rest of my work was embargoed for the next five years, i wouldn't be happy with that, but that's a negotiation we have yet to have. I am fairly confident that because they are generally open access and that my work here has almost zero impact on their commercial interests that that would be an issue. Here it's fine. My supervisor is sponsored by Welcome Trust so we have to publish everything open access anyway so that's not a problem.

ANSWER: Yes. I am working on a mosquito called which has a naturally occurring infection with who's genome was recently sequenced and published as such. The publication said that the annotated, fully formed version of the genome was available on ricroscope which is a microbial genol site which is wasn't when i checked it was still listed as a private project and you needed a password to enter. So after three e-mails i was promised access from the author. I was promised access after i first e-mailed the person and nothing happened. Then i followed it up with two more e-mails and still nothing happened. As far as I'm aware and i haven't checked in a month it's still listed as a private project despite the fact that it's been published in a journal as available on their site which i don't think is very fair. But i basically gave up as they have put the raw sequence on the NCBI general bank website. For my purposes i didn't really need the fully annotated genome. I just needed the raw sequence and i can work with that. But it still means that had i wanted to do anything a bit more complicated then it would have been handy to have the already analysed version. I didn't think it was correct to publish something as available when it wasn't. So i have come across that. I have come across stuff not so much not published but not published in anyway that makes it easy to copy and re-use it as well. Just tables and images of DNA sequencing things that you have to sit down and type out manually as well which is quite annoying. I think that is probably my main, the genome is probably the main one i have come across where actually i haven't been able to access information despite going through the proper channels and theoretically i shouldn't have to go through any channels as it should be there. I can't think of any major ones. Most journals i use information from, we subscribe to if they are pay for access so that's not been too much of a problem. Although I'm at a very rich university.

ANSWER: As i alluded to earlier, my remit is expanded quite a lot since we set up Cottage Labs. Before i was mostly interested in repositories and interoperability of the repositories. In the last three years or so we've done projects surrounding the use of and the interchange of research information. So research information is the meta data about the search. So it's who got funded what, by whom, to produce what research output? So it's about connecting together the people, the organizations, the inputs and the outputs of the search. So we've done a lot of work with how to represent that data and how to exchange that data and how to analyze that data to produce useful business intelligence for institutions and we've done that in the open using open standards. SERIF in particular with open data. The gateway to research data specifically from the research council in the UK. At the same time we've also taken a lot of interest in the bibliographic materials. So working with the open access journals, who have a corpus of 1.6 million journal articles that are open access and some ten thousand journals are open access and we are helping them build a tool that will keep track of all of that bibliography and makes the links and text available to people who are searching through their site. So that kind of more operational stuff for researchers as opposed to research managers and then we have also been working with licensing conditions. We have a project called the Open Article Gauge where we actually attempt to determine the licensing conditions of individual articles and the purpose of that work is actually driven by a use case from the funders which is to understand how open access mandates are being complied with. So there's another aspect. So these three different aspects - the bibliography, the research information and the funder mandate all sort of interact quite nicely together in the various projects we've been doing over the last three years and I've also been involved in quite a bit of standardisation to help these different kinds of information systems talk to each other. Sword 2 is a project that I've been a technical lead on for a couple of years. It's a deposit protocol for moving content between scholarly systems and I've also been involved in ResourceSync which has been a product of the open archives initiative for exchanging change lists of information between systems. So again slightly repository focused but not strictly repository focused. Large scale interchange of data between systems. So yes, a broad range of things, of various bits of the puzzle which we are starting to put together around about now which i think is why open scholarship is a much more interesting topic right now.

ANSWER: I think the best way is communication. One of the things we do is that we use a lot of communication tools to make sure that customers are fully informed on what we're up to. So we use an agile methodology for development. We have weekly meetings with the clients by Skype or Hangout or whatever. We have a collaborative notepad where we all can share content throughout meetings or in between meetings. If we want to bring something up in a meeting then it goes in a notepad and then it doesn't get lost and then we use traditional or perhaps modern traditional software engineering tools. We have a version control repository which the clients all have access to. We have an issue tracker where clients can see what issues we are encountering and they can comment on those or raise their own issues. I would say that that's the main approach we have for dealing with that. The consequence of that is that actually people aren't used to that level of communication from a development agency. A lot of old fashioned, non open sourced development agencies don't behave like that. They work much more waterfall style so sometimes it can be a bit of a culture shock for people when they work with us and see how much we talk to them and how much information we ask them for .
QUESTION: So continuing with that but going back to Richard. So you said that a lot of the issues that have come up are when you have to interface with the customer. So do you have any particular ways of sorting through those kinds of problems? How do you deal with that on a daily basis on a project?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: So I'll start with waterfall. Waterfall is the conical bad way to run a software engineering project, which has unfortunately become enshrined as the way to run big software engineering projects. Effectively it starts with a design process, it goes on to a development process and then to a testing process. Strictly in that order and at the end of testing if there are any problems it goes round to the very beginning again and works it's way back down the stack. Hence it's name the waterfall. It only goes in one direction, it falls down the development process. The problems with this are that sometimes you discover when you're doing the development something that might impact the design and the correct thing to do is actually to go back to the design immediately and try and resolve the issue rather than pushing on through to testing and then coming back at the end. This process tends to lead to long projects which by the end don't necessarily meet the clients requirements. Either their requirements have moved on or you didn't get their requirements quite right and you didn't notice. So agile attempts to address this by a set of principles which can ultimately be boiled down to - would you please just talk to each other, as i like to call it. The process of developing software in Agile is very iterative on very short cycles with all of the stakeholders involved in the process on the way. So the design, development and testing is all happening simultaneously and when a problem is encountered stakeholders are immediately aware and a discussion can take place and a resolution can be come up with straight away and you change direction based on changing requirements as quickly as possible. The result being much more communication with a focus on producing something at the end that is actually what the client wants at the end of the project. For reference, the Agile manifesto can be used now.
QUESTION: Can you quickly, not in a lot of detail give an explanation of what you mean there by agile and waterfall?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: Well the answer is that i know what I'm building within a particular time frame, So i know what I'm building within the next hour, or the next day or the next week depending on how big and likely to change the requirement is. But I'm kind of hesitant to get fixed requirements in my head which will last for months because these are almost always, they seem like a good idea if you're a developer but they're actually not because almost inevitably what happens is that the client isn't happy at the end of several months of development with very little communication feedback. So I'd rather shrink the time frame during which i focus on building something.
QUESTION: Emanuil can you give me a bit of feedback on, given this process that Richard's describing it's Agile nature, how does that impact you when you're working? If you are trying to build a piece of software on a project, how do you deal with the constant changing to what it is you're building?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: Yes OK. I would say that your statement is slightly wrong. I would say the requirements are never wrong. Requirements simply are what you think at the time. So the requirements at the beginning could well be right for what you think you wanted at the beginning and at the end the requirements that you have should be right for the thing that you've actually built. So they don't necessarily need to be the same but that doesn't make either of them wrong. As Emanuil alluded to earlier, the process of development is also the process of discovery. You learn stuff that you didn't know before and that causes you to change the way that you think so you necessarily change your requirements. So that's the sign of a healthy project, is one where the requirements are constantly reviewed and ones that are no longer relevant are discarded and new requirements come in. So i think it's a good thing that requirements change all the time and sometimes in the process of development you're learning that what you think is a requirement isn't actually a requirement it's a hangover from a previous process and often the only way to learn that is by really digging into it and understanding what it is you're trying to do and building the software and discovering that actually there is a better way of doing this and therefore this requirement is not the requirement we thought it was. So it comes from my time at University of Edinburgh where we were working on putting thesis online and we were told early on in the project that it was a requirement that people sign some kind of license agreeing to some terms of use before they read any thesis and the people who were responsible for the print thesis were adamant that this was a requirement. So we put it on our list but we were slightly suspicious of it and as we went through the development it became clear that replicating this requirement wasn't really possible in the web environment and after a bit of to-ing and fro-ing we discovered that actually the reason they wanted people to click through a licence was the current process was that people would sign a piece of paper before they received the print thesis but the reason they signed the piece of paper was not so they had signed the piece of paper but so the librarian responsible for the thesis knew where the one copy of that print thesis was and when we understood that we understood that the requirement was not - you must click through a licence, the requirement was - we mustn't loose the copy of this thesis and so that changes the way that we approach the problem. The problem was no longer one of licensing, the problem was preservation and storage. So there is a learning process to be had by running through the development.
QUESTION: So with this issue then around what you are describing as the requirements that come up at the start of the project but aren't actually useful over a long period of time, why do you think that it is that that happens? What happens to those, were the requirements wrong at the start? Were they wrong at the end? Did they go wrong somewhere in the middle? Was it the communication? Is there any clear point at which these requirements seem to have failed to in the end to deliver what the user wants? Richard do you want to start?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: That isn't my own in the sense that I'm not working within it?
QUESTION: That sort of issue then sounds like it could be something where you encounter a boundary problem in your work because if you have to tell someone who has a vested interest in a particular process, that that process should change then presumably they may not be very amenable to that given that in some cases i guess you don't even work there. Like in that example you were at Edinburgh say but as developers at Cottage Labs you then have to work with other people in their own setting of which you are not a part. Is this a problem that you need to overcome? Let's start with Emanuil. Have you Emanuil encountered this issue where you've needed to make a suggestion that changes the way that something gets done in an organization that isn't your own?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: Well i would usually, the way that i would deal with it is i would just present my own arguments to the organization. So the question to ask - is why would i want to change anything? So the reason i want to change anything is presumably because i am focusing in some way on the clients of that organization or the stakeholders of that organization. Which is something that the organization itself should also be thinking about. So whenever i suggest a change to process, i am simply trying to help them in a way deliver better value, or experience or whatever it is their doing to their customers and those don't have to be paying customer they can be a community of people, they can be anybody. I have found that as long as i stay focused on that the organizations and the projects I've worked with are pretty receptive to change. Although having said that i have been in a similar situation but not in Cottage Labs within the last three years where i worked within an organization which was a university but within a specific department of a university which is business information systems and we had as customers all the other departments within the university. So when they had a process such as sending out thirty six thousand pieces of paper such as the accommodation office of the university in this case, they acted and reacted like a different organization to my own. So the way that i dealt with that was again that i focused on what i thought the needs of their customers were and i explained what i think those things were to them and what they can do about it because people don't necessarily realise what they can do with technology or with the time and the attention of developers. So i explained the possibilities to them and after that it was up to them. One thing I'm careful of is i don't usually push my solutions. I make suggestions but ultimately it's those peoples responsibility to satisfy their clients and to evolve their communities and to satisfy their paying customers. So ultimately that responsibility lies with them and i have to believe that they will want to do the right thing for their customers.
QUESTION: Yes so as part of Cottage Labs you work on the development for another organization and in that organization they may have some processes that as Richard described where you need to sign a piece of paper but you realise as a developer that actually that process needs to change, how do you deal with that if it's come up at all?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: Yes actually. I would say that there are a couple of other things. First thing is that conveniently for us a lot of people that we work with are already committed to change. They are interested in having us come in and do something for them that they couldn't previously do. You know, they want to modernise or they want to change a process and that's really cool and really exciting because we get to do lots of crazy and interesting stuff. What Emanuil says stands for individual clients who need a little bit of pressure on them but there's another kind of organization that is the community. When we do projects that involve more than one stakeholder and i use stakeholder instead of client because a lot of the projects we do are publicly funded and have a public benefit aspect to them. That can be a lot more challenging to convince people that change is necessary or possible and you get a lot of push back because these are not people that are paying you to do work for then they are people where the work you are doing will impact them in some unknown way. So a good example is the UKRISS project which is a long project to develop a profile of research information data or an interchange between institutions and funder's and everyone essentially wants this but everyone is slightly afraid of what it really means to do that because it's very complex and it has consequences to everyone who's involved in this area. They are going to have to change in some way shape or form and they are not totally clear on how, and their not totally clear on how much that will cost and their not sure that what they want is being absolutely so you get a lot of resistance when you do that kind of thing and as of yet people don't know for sure how or whether we'll be able to successfully change the community but what we attempted to do to help people along was demonstrate why doing it the way UKRISS was proposing it would be a good thing. So essentially prototyping demonstrated so that people could see - ahh if we follow the approach that UKRISS is recommending then we will get these other benefits and it kind of helps people see why they should change. But that's a very slow process, much slower than having a conversation with a client.
QUESTION: Richard have you got anything you want to add to that?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: Actually i guess mine is quite conventional really. When i find an interesting solution or when i find a particular software project or software library that i think could be the foundation of interesting solutions to my problems, i try to follow it's development. So i subscribe to e-mail updates usually, twitter feeds, search. The other thing that i do is i subscribe to communities, to community updates which are usually people in the software development community who curate together information about happenings in the comunity within the last week and then will push out updated either via twitter or e-mail. One of the ones that I'm following that has been really, really helpful is Python mailing list which is basically news on Python projects which is a language we use in Cottage Labs quite a lot. So i guess i mostly, to recap it, i mostly rely on other people's curated information that i find interesting and other people having asked the same question before and me being able to find the question they asked and the answer to it.

ANSWER: I usually tend to find it for free. Some of them do require subscription or payment and i usually immediately discard those. There is a network effect to that, i know that other people in my community will think the same. ANSWER: I would guess that my experiences are similar. If I'm adopting a new technology my two initial things are, first of all - do i know anyone who already knows it and can i ask them? You two for example are my go to guys for some stuff because you know as expert programmers you have insights in to things i might want to learn how to do. So i quite often actually go to a peer group first, possibly to the online documentation which again as Emanuil said which i would expect to get for free and then if it's a new Python module or something like that i will just install it and start playing about with it and when i get stuck i tend to just Google the errors. In particular we haven't mentioned anything by name so i will - Stack overflow has enormous resources available to answer all kinds of questions and in almost all areas there is a hit in Stack overflow for the problem you're having and that is all available for free and you have to register if you want to add content but you don't have to register if you just want to read content. But if you do add content you can post your own questions there and you can get answers back and it's very expert community on there. An interesting feature there, coming back to what Emanuil was saying about there being some sites where you have to pay, i quite often encounter sites which have adverts on them and or suggest that you might want to join their specialist user community which seem to just be mirroring content from Stack Overflow. So it's almost like the private or pay section is leeching content from the public section of the internet in order to get you to pay for stuff which is already available for free. The other thing that I'd add just to back up my open source credentials is that sometimes when I'm really stuck i do open source code and i have a look and I've resolved issues with software before by doing that.
QUESTION: Richard have you got any similar experiences or different experiences to that?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: I would say that if anything it's getting better. I mean open source had a big head start on open access and open scholarship in terms of the culture in the community. There's so many resources available online for software developers and the resources are just getting bigger and better so i would say that if anything it's going to get easier. Although of course obviously there is more stuff to trawl through to find the answers but the answers are out there certainly.
QUESTION: So we've got an idea on what you've been working on and how you've been working on it and a bit of an idea about how you go about doing the work yourself. So could we talk a little bit about how you see this work going on in the future. Do you find say your current processes for searching on line for the information that you need and having it freely available, do you suspect that that is something that will be sustained? Do you expect to be able to do that for the next few years or are you expecting that situation to change at all? Richard do you want to start?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: Yes i would definitely expect all this information to still be available for free and in fact i would feel quite strongly about this because as Richard said open source has had a really big head start on this and i wouldn't want to loose that and further more there is something about that culture which is really appealing. When i was younger and just getting into computing i used to be fascinated with, specifically maybe a bit strangely with system administrators who would maintain their own corner of the Internet. They had their own machine and they were connected their machine was connected to all the other machines but they would do anything well most things in order to maintain that connectivity, in order to keep that material available which usually meant free for the public to read as well. I would want to keep this cultural tradition i guess and pass those values on to people that i work with. Say if i worked with younger people or somebody inexperienced in the field. I would try to teach them those values.
QUESTION: So we've got an idea on what you've been working on and how you've been working on it and a bit of an idea about how you go about doing the work yourself. So could we talk a little bit about how you see this work going on in the future. Do you find say your current processes for searching on line for the information that you need and having it freely available, do you suspect that that is something that will be sustained? Do you expect to be able to do that for the next few years or are you expecting that situation to change at all? Richard do you want to start?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: I certainly hope that we will be able to pass on the values. There's a lot of interesting work in the pipeline. Both for Cottage Labs and for the open source higher education sector as a whole. There's lots of interesting work around open access compliance and mandates and how to make the open access infrastructure as good technically as the existing publishing infrastructure and there's a lot of interest in doing that so i'm anticipating there will be a lot of work on infrastructure for open access in the coming years and certainly within Cottage Labs as you know there are only a few of us we're pretty good at what we do even if i do say so myself that i think that if we wanted to pass on skills to a new generation or a younger group of programmers who have an opportunity to do so and also expand the company to do more of this cool stuff that's coming up.
QUESTION: So following on a bit from the teaching them values to new people or younger people. How does that overall fit in with your plans for work in the future? Richard if we go back to you. Do you have an idea of what you're going to be doing in the next few years that as Emanuil described will be passing on the kinds of values you have or alternatively do you have different or changing values that you intend to pass on? Does that some how tie up with your work?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: Well that's a good question. Well i can answer the second one first of all. Social problems are always harder than technical problems, that's a rule of thumb. I would say that the technology that we need is not mostly is not too complex. I mean it's not necessarily straight forward but we are approaching open access infrastructure services so publishing services, peer review services, text mining services whatever it is that we need to expose and disseminate and manage all of this scholarly content. We are approaching the delivery of those services in the same way that developers approached the delivery of open source software. So an actual installable piece of software is built by a collection of people and is installed by individuals who are interested in using it. Services are slightly different in that somebody somewhere has to ultimately run it. So we are approaching the development of the services in a similar way that we're approaching the development of open source software. Which is that groups of people who are interested in this stuff are clubbing together and developing the technology and developing the service provision and carrying out the culture change required. So there are some organizational challenges around building the technology that are separate from the social challenges of getting people to use it. But i also think that when we move into a more open development of infrastructure that we have the opportunity to build more cool difficult technology. You know we are already working with some very high end search and text analytical stuff just at Cottage Labs and we're not even on the from line of that really crazy stuff that you can do with text analysis. So I'm sure that there are some hard technical challenges that can be tackled but i don't think that they are problems, i think they are opportunities by moving into a more open development space. So no i don't think the technical challenges are particularly large but i think the organizational challenges aboutf building the technology are quite difficult and i think the social challenges will always be a hard problem and all you can do is build the technology, show people how great it is and use that to lead the way
QUESTION: Do you think given what you were saying there about the building of the infrastructure, given the problems that you've worked on and the ways you've worked on them and the values that you use yourself and how those values do or don't get disseminated, is the building of this infrastructure that you're talking about something that you see as having large technical problems or is it large social problems and which of those is harder or easier?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: How i see problems being resolved in the future. I do agree that it's always more difficult to resolve social problems. It's also, sometimes i do forget that you have to have a technological solution in mind when it's really needed because there are a surprising amount of people who are just unable to both do the technology and source building of the technology within their professional networks. So actually progress depends on the people who know the right technology or who know the right people and build it. That's my current feeling about this list and so therefore it's important to get the right people together, That's just something that i think i will try to focus on more once i get the opportunity to, not to just focus on immediate technological problems to resolve.
QUESTION: Emanuil do you have anything you'd like to add to that?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: I guess i would add explicitly, we have pretty much talked around this, the way that open should work essentially, open source has really pointed the way to how open can really, really work and really get people engaged. It works by, effectively it's vendor independence. You can build the stuff that you want. It's about the freedom to build the stuff you want and for different people to offer you the services around the same artifact if you like. So in the desktop market Red Hat for example offer a Linux distribution and they will deploy it to the organization and they will supply and support it just like Microsoft support windows. But if you ever get annoyed with Red Hat, you can simply stop paying them to support the software and either support it yourself or pay someone else to support it. So this kind of service model is exactly the same kind of model that i think open scholarship ultimately needs to fit into somehow. The stuff is free but the services around it might not necessarily be free but you want the ability for anyone to provide those services so that you maximise competition and therefore increase quality.
QUESTION: I don't have any more specific questions to raise, is there anything that either of you two would like to bring up before we finish the call?
NAME: Richard

ANSWER: Yes, i think currently there is a lot of focus on open access and open scholarship to simply push forward, to advance the field as much as possible, within the shortest time frame possible and sometimes i think it's interesting to look back and see what's current in the mainstream and analyze those processes but within the context of open access and also think about how that gap could be bridged. A lot of people shout for just discarding all the old stuff and bringing in all the new stuff and that's OK that's how change gets pushed, that's progress gets pushed but I'd be quite interested in the social and business aspects of backwards compatibility quote on quote and whether it wouldn't be possible to tap into the professional, you just tap into the people networks that comprise the current mainstream within scientific publishing and convince them little by little with carefully crafted examples and with carefully crafted statements to move on and to change parts of their processes. Basically i guess what I'm saying is to treat the people who are already doing this work right now, with a little bit more respect and think a bit more about them instead of simply thinking about change. Change and progress is very good but i think it's also interesting to think about the current status quo and see it from an almost condescending angle but also a more compassionate angle and think of how we can help them with change rather than just discard them.
QUESTION: I don't have any more specific questions to raise, is there anything that either of you two would like to bring up before we finish the call?
NAME: Emanuil

ANSWER: My name is Theo Andrew and I'm part of the Scholarly Communication team here at the University of Edinburgh Library and our team is a new team set up to help and support researchers within the University of Edinburgh, to publish their work in various new and creative ways and also to support them with research funders open access policies and also recently we've been supporting researchers with research assessment exercises like the Ref.
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So the library has been interested in open access over the last ten years for a number of reasons. Historically the library has been interested due to the Serial's Crisis and journal subscription prices have increased yearly and general library budgets are not been increasing in line with that. In the early years open access was seen as a way of pushing back against that and maybe seen as an alternative. That's some early motivation for the library to be involved. But i think it goes beyond that now. The library has been early adopters of repository software. It has been an un-organice process from adopting early typologies like repositories and fitting them for use within an institutional setting like a university and looking at how they can be used so using them in different scenarios so technologies like D Space. We deploy them in various situations and we work with open source software to try and fulfill a need for the university. So there is a whole reason background about why we are being involved with open access and open source. Our team has grown organically around this. So in the early days there were just one or two people involved in project work and over the years the project work has grown into services and as those services need staffing to actually support them within the institution, we've had the team grow. So we started off in the early years with PhD thesis and electronic versions and developing infrastructure for the university to be able to look after electronic PhD thesis. We've moved beyond that through E Prints and looking at how we can use repository systems to make the scholarship from the university open. But we have also moved into other areas such as research assessment exercises like the Ref. So our teams been supporting that, the collection of the data behind that and looking at various systems to be able to collect and record that information. We've seen like an evolution of simple repository systems right through to Kris type systems that we have today so current research systems that we are currently using to not just collect information about research outputs, and not just outputs themselves also tie them in with, tie them to research projects that they are associated with and people. So we are kind of moving away from silo's of information to actual connected information that people can use in interesting ways.
QUESTION: So this is quite a new group that has been set up that you've joined. What have you been working on that's led to that and why did it come about and why did you want to get involved in it?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So it's interesting that you mention that. We are currently trying to tease apart subscriptions, prices, costings and open access and they are two separate but related areas and we're seeing a lot of costs. We're in a transition period now where publishers investigating open access business models whilst retaining traditional print business models, traditional subscription based ones. So we're in a period of evolution now where we're seeing the change and how the library reacts to that.
QUESTION: So do you think then that that kind of move, because you mentioned the problem with the budgets and the increasing sales prices, is that quite strongly related to that particular issue or are there other reasons for moving in that direction anyway?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So from our perspective we are really interested in the information that's created within the university and making sure that it's curated in a professional way. So researchers publish their work in journals, we have the publishers take on this role and they will publish the journals and make sure that they're archived they're available, they're curated. There is also a lot of information that is created that is not looked after by anyone apart from the university so we're in a position that spans across the institution and we can pick up these objects, these items, these pieces of scholarship, these outputs and we can make sure that we look after them. So we started off with PhD thesis. So we've always had a mandate to look after hard copies but increasingly now material is being made in electronic format and is born digital so we're having to make sure that we are prepared to take this information and look after it and that's where repositories initially stepped in. They were platforms that we could take and use to start looking after this information but we quickly realised those other born digital information that was being created in the university that no-one else was looking after. So the problem is that a lot of this information might be ephemeral. So someone might set up a web page and it would be available for five or ten years but then what about the long term. The university has been around since the fifteen hundreds, we're looking at a long term game here so we need to try and build systems and processes that can look after information in those kind of timescales. So we're looking at our repository system as a way to take on board this information and make sure that it's available in a format for future generations. So we started off with PhD thesis but are kind of moving on beyond that to other forms of grey literature and now we are also looking at other forms of information produced within the university. So quite often we have researchers coming to us who want to publish their own material free from the constraints of traditional scholarly publishers so they want to set up their own journal and yet there's nothing stopping you setting up your own journal, creating a web site - and there you go, you've got a journal. But once again there is this problem with ephemeral information, is it still going to be there in five years, ten years, twenty years time? So we've started using the open system software journal to create a platform for scholars and researchers within the university to publish their own journals and we can provide a platform for them to do this that is managed in a professional way and they can get on with the management side of running a journal but we can worry about the technology side. So we started from one place but we are organically growing into other areas.
QUESTION: So with the work in the library then on repositories using D Space and so and looking at the open access offerings, what do you think, what is the current thinking around, are you looking at those as things that you are trying to offer as services alternative then to journal subscription or are you looking to newer or different kinds of journals to a different kind of service or is it a bit of a mixture?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: There is no current standards of digital preservation that we are currently employing, We are just keeping it relevant at the minute. So we just follow best practices for information management. We put the content on line and make sure it's backed up and that the severs are backed up . There's disaster and recovery plans around that but we haven't fully implemented any digital preservation plans but i think quite often these form our of necessity. So it's a work in progress.
QUESTION: So how would you go about then archiving that kind of material that you mentioned there - the ephemeral, digital, a web page here and there through to the journal of where you've got them on the open journal system? But that in itself is still the current version of it running, are you moving into backing up those things in an archive for future generations or what is your process there?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So i originally trained as a Geologist and have a doctorate in Geology and part of that process was involved in researching literature from the seventies in quite obscure literature from French PhD thesis where there might be one or two copies available and the copies of these information were kind of shared around supervisors and you'd have a tatty paper copy that you'd be able to borrow for a week or so and then you'd make a photocopy of this and that would get passed around and it was very difficult to get hold of the information - maps, literature. It was one of the most difficult parts of writing the thesis was actually actually to do the literary review, actually that should be the easiest. You should be able to have the information and then carry out your research on top of that. But actually getting it to understand what has been published before has been a problem. That kind of got me interested in how to publish PhD thesis more effectively and when i finished my doctorate, there was a project at the university setting up E thesis repository. So as I've had background in kind of writing a thesis i understood the problems in that and i wanted to be involved in setting up a platform process for students from Edinburgh to be able to share their work more effectively than people from previous generations who couldn't.
QUESTION: So can you tell a bit more about why you personally then are involved and if there are any reasons beyond it just being a job or do yo have any personal interest in these things?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So my interest really lies in how to improve current processes of sharing information and i come from a background of Geo sciences where it's a mixed bag of people - some are really computer literate and others are illiterate. You're sharing information via re-prints or paper copies that you send to people and so coming from this lowest common denominator where people are kind of stuck and wanting to move beyond that to have institutional systems where people can share information a lot easier and preserve it and make it available in formats.
