QUESTION: So it seems then your interest in doing this work is quite strongly linked to actually having produced similar work yourself and thinking about how other people would be able to continue doing so?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So when i was writing my thesis quite often we'd look at previous PhD thesis produced by other students from the same supervisor and the only way to get copies of these was to actually borrow a copy of your supervisors, which is you'd go into his office and there would be a whole range of the hard back thesis on the shelves and you could borrow a thesis and look at it and have an understanding. It was an informal library. If you came to the library and tried to borrow a copy you were told - sorry you're a post graduate student you're not allowed to borrow a copy and you're like well how am i supposed to consult this literature and use it? Because at the time on staff members were allowed to borrow a thesis. So there were a lot of barriers in place to actually access information and consult the literature and so quite often you'd have informal work around where you'd borrow your supervisors copy and you'd go if you wanted to see a work from a different university you'd have to try and get a copy through inter library loans and if that didn't work you'd go directly to the supervisor there and borrow their copy and that's not a particularly sustainable way of doing things, that's not easy. How does someone who can't travel to visit your supervisor, how can they borrow the work? So the early project i was involved in was setting up a repository system for the University of Edinburgh for the students to use to upload their PhD thesis into a repository and make them available via the web on an open access basis. Fast forward a few years and it went from a project into a service where the university actually passed a mandate in 2005 where all students must submit an electronic copy to the university library. So now we have gone from a system where people could only access a hard copy from their supervisors but now their is an electronic copy in the library which they can consult if they want. So i think that's quite a big step change that we've introduced.
QUESTION: Do you think then that that is something that is happening? Do you think it's easier now to find these bits and pieces of information or to look on line for something that way than it was when you did it and given that your work is looking at people who have done similar things in the seventies, is it easier or harder?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So there are a lot of subject discipline differences in attitudes towards sharing thesis and dissertations on line. So for science and engineering it's quite common for people to put their thesis on their own web pages and so for example computer sciences are very happy with putting their content in repositories. Other disciplines like humanities and social sciences were a lot slower to come on board. So some subjects like divinity or law their has been a hesitancy to put electronic thesis on line for anyone to read. Recently history has been one subject area tha has been talking about having on line embargo's for a minimum of five years just to protect history. So we're dealing with a base line of a wide range of different attitudes towards sharing dissertations. So currently the situation we have here is that students must submit an electronic copy but they can request a one year embargo to the electronic version and at the end of that year they can request for it to be extended. However we are trying to move the norms to having material that is open. In some cases there might be situations where it's not appropriate to share this information, meaning because it's commercially sensitive or someone is applying for a patent so then we have to have an embargo or there might be sensitive material in there, patient confidentiality. So we have to have some way of having embargo's in there. But it's a light touch, we try and have as many thesis as open as possible. So currently we have around seven thousand items in our repository of which four or five thousand are PhD thesis of which four hundred have some kind of time limited embargo. So we are talking less than one percent ball park figure.
QUESTION: And that electronic copy is then available to anyone?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So take for example referencing for a published PhD thesis. You would give the author, date and title and say it's an unpublished PhD thesis from the University of Edinburgh. For the papers I've written certainly people haven't done that before we've referenced a PhD. Now typically if someone wanted to go through to the references and check the material and read the material, they would find it very difficult to obtain a copy of that thesis as it's on a shelf on the library and they may or may not be able to read that piece of literature which seems kind of backwards. If you are referencing a piece of work that you know people can't access, so morally that felt wrong. It leads to the question where you can cite a piece of work that you know people can't access, there's the possibility of fraud creeping into the work. Where as if you move to the situation we are in now where you can just cite a URL and say this is the location where i accessed this material. You can go there too and have it instantly. It's a complete step change. So the situation where we have gone from and to is a lot better.
QUESTION: So I'm quite interested in this point where in the past you had to look at the works that were say present in a supervisors collection and you would get a copy of that and read that and look at that and you then had to reference that you had done so in your literature review, and similarly now someone might get a copy from a repository or from a web page or from a subject repository rather than an institutional repository and they'll have to reference that. How do you think then that situation has changed, often there's this idea that referencing what you read and where it was very straight forward in the past and now has become hard but it seems from what you were saying that the copies that you had access to are not necessarily the golden ones?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So with our repository systems at the Edinburgh research archive they built them with a long term mind set from the start. So when you put content in there that you want to maintain for the long term, we would try and have a versioning system so if you add new material and want to change it it's kind of clear what people are accessing. Typically for thesis literature, once you have submitted a thesis it doesn't change. So in that respect it's fairly simple. Other types of material once again very rarely changes. So other types of information that we are collecting we are putting into repositories are exam papers from the university. Typically these were just put into, collected in hard back books that people could use at the library and photocopy. We are now collecting pdf's which we were putting on web pages but we are now putting in repository systems.
QUESTION: So this would be an interesting point to move from what you have been doing and are doing to support that then the problems of the future then because of course the ease with which you can reference a URL is sometimes compared with ease of which someone can change what is available at that URL. So are you currently doing anything or looking at anything for the future to start to consider those issues? Like if i reference a piece of work right now and i say it's at this address, how does someone know later?, the simple solution is that like you said the work is ephemeral, it's no longer there. What if it still there how do you know it's the same?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: There's a process of version control. There's administrative meta data that's created. So when you add in items you can see who and when added an item and when it's changed etc.
QUESTION: So when they are in the repository system i guess there is a group of people who are running that repository and the item then at that URL doesn't change or at least it has to go through some kind of administrative process?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So previously we'd been working on the Research Excellence framework and the reason I'm familiar with that is that it's a process where every seven years or so the university submits a return and the outputs of the university are judged and ranked and it's extremely important for the university cause a lot of the research budget for the university comes from the performance from the Ref and the library is involved in terms of collecting publication details and in the last few research assessment exercises and now the Ref, it's felt like a convulsive exercise where it's just a rush, a panic to gather the information. So we have now put in place a current research search information system that makes it easy to maintain a profile, a record of what's been produced at the university. So it used to be the case that if you asked someone at the university what does the university do, what are it's outputs? It would be very difficult for that person to find out. What they would actually probably do is take a round about view. They'd probably go to Web of Science and do an institutional search there and try and work out what has been published formally. So if you think about that it's kind of a strange way to go about what you as an institution is doing by going to a third party asking them well what have we done, being told what you've done. Isn't it a far better situation to record what you're doing and have your own systems in place. So we've now set up a current research information system to do this and the idea is that we collect information about research outputs, all different types of publications not just journal articles, conference proceedings, book chapters but everything. Including areas of impact, so people have done press, news items, clippings other performance indicators are collected as well. So we've also been reporting citation data from different sources and we are also linking outputs to people as well. So that when people move universities we can then send a record with that person to a new institution and say here's a file of all of these peoples publications and all of their projects and similarly if someone comes to us from a different institution they can bring a similar portfolio with them. So that's not in place yet but we are working towards that.
QUESTION: What other areas then of the group that you're in now, what sorts of things are you working on now where you're looking to do something new or different with over the next couple of years?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: So the new RCUK policy has been in place for nearly a year now and we're coming up to the reporting period on that and there's a couple of aspects on the reporting. So RCUK have given the institution a block grant to pay for general article processing charges. So we'll be reporting on how much money the institution spends on these APC's and so RCUK can then look at it's investment and see what it's bought for the money. The other side of the reporting is to tell which grants haven't made their research outputs open. So how do you know that? First of all we have to collect all the publication information from the university. So we'll be collecting that information and putting that into our Kris system and then trying to link projects to that information so that we can quickly query that information. So in the first year RCUK asked for a 45% compliance figure. So we are hoping we can meet that figure by collecting all of the information and putting it into our Kris system and then querying it. It's reliant on us getting all of the information and linking it to grants as well. Other research funders like the Welcome Trust take a slightly different approach. So they require all of their funded research to be made open and they way they judge that is if it has a pub med central ID or not. So it has to be in pub med central. If it doesn't have a pub med central iD then as far as they are concerned it's not open. So they check all of the publications that a researcher submits to the Welcome, they check to see if it's got a pub med central ID. So if a researcher is submitting a grant application and they have that publication list but it doesn't have a pub med central ID they then discount it, they say well it's not open access so we're not interested in it. So they are taking a tougher line than RCUK, they are saying all of our research, 100% has to be open access and have a pub med central ID. If it's not made open then we're having financial sanctions as well. They are looking at an article basis of 100%. So we are trying to help researchers at Edinburgh comply with that so if a researcher comes to us and says i'm submitting a grant application but i don't have a pub med central ID, help what do i do? We can assist them in the process of getting a pub med central ID wither by submitting it to pub med central and deposing a manuscript that way or retrospectively going back and requesting an APC fee.
QUESTION: Does that then tie in with at all the recent mandate changes from RCUk saying that if they fund your work, the work has to be open and accessible? Are you doing anything to check on that?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: It's becoming smoother. So we've set our scholarly communication team up to be a support service to support researchers. Quite a common theme we get when talking to researchers is that this is something they have planned for. It's another admin task that they don't want to spend their time doing. So we're saying - you don't have to, we can do it for you and there is a team of people here that will assist you to reinterpret your way through journal copy write policies or research funder mandates. Work out what you need to do to make your work open whether that's deposit in a repository which we prefer or if your funder mandates that you deposit it in to the pub med central then you might have to pay a gold processing charge. So we're here to take that admin overhead from researchers and so from that point of view we're helping them, supporting them. So we're being received a lot more gratefully. Rather than someone saying make your work open, here's what you need to do. So instead of telling people what to do we're saying we're here to help and that's been seen as a lot better. Going forwards i think the main impact that I've seen over the last few years are research funders with open access mandates and that's really grabbing peoples attentions and forcing them to engage with open access in ways which they hadn't necessarily had to before. Researchers need help and support with that so we're in the ideal position to help them go through this transition period. We are in a unique and privileged position really where we can see in between researchers and councils and we can see, we actually have time to look at the data and interpret that so we are actually seeing how much investors are spending on open access and we can aggregate that data and analyze it and actually make people aware of the issues. So currently we're seeing we're going through a transition period where universities are paying for subscription access to their journals but they are also paying article processing charges to make them open access and currently it's quite an open field the markets quite elastic. We are seeing a wide variability in article processing charges, we're not seeing anyone reporting on these, we're not seeing anyone taking responsibility so i think part of our role is to actually report on this and say this is how much the university is paying for these deals and try and be as open with the data as possible. So we're one of the early adopters of open data. Last year we published a Welcome Trust mandate on line. This year we've seen the Welcome Trust publish their own data and we'd like to feel that we're partly responsible for planting the seen in their head that they should be doing this. We've asked them to do it but they haven't done it in quite a while but now they are publishing their own data because they are seeing that when you have a closed system people will charge the maximum price for a product that they can get away with and if you have a closed system then there's no reason to be competitive. But if we publish all of our data we can say hey look this is exactly what we're paying and then we can start to see a fair charge for open access publishing charges. Love them or hate them they are not going away they are here with us so we have to try and manage the process a bit better.
QUESTION: So going back to round off then, i your work how is that particular aspect going, and where say you're aware of these things and you have to work on these issues and you have to work with researchers who also maybe are trying to deal with these issues, do you find that there is good collaboration there or do you find it's difficult to bridge the library researcher boundary or is it quite smooth or becoming smooth?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: We can only really report on what people are paying. We are in a position to actually aggregate that data and publish it and do some analysis of it. So you know we could say that pure open access journals tend to charge less but library journals charge a lot more, discuss. We can't really make value judgements on that, we can only really say - here are the facts and then we can publish that and make people aware. What we need to do for the future is to make sure that the institution gets the best deal possible it can for publishing. So we would expect for example our journal subscriptions to be in line with our open access spend and in the recent Finch report it was mentioned that there should be no net increase, it should be, it should kind of pay for itself. So we need to make sure that the amounts the institution is paying as a whole to the publishing industry and try and get the best deal possible.
QUESTION: Do you think then that's something from a library perspective that you want to get more involved in? As this different model comes about with the APC's is to be able to say - these are the prices, this is what it's worth and then sort of discuss whether that's value or whether it should be cheaper or more expensive?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: I think we're on a role talking about the future of publishing. I'd be interested, one thing personally interested in, is how we can experiment with ways of future scholarly communication. So the library's kind of supporting this through the seas of open journal systems and trying to put the power of scholarly communication back in the hands of the researchers and let them be actually able to make the decisions of who can access the material and when and how they want to publish. So I'd be interested in trying to get the library involved more in projects and experiments like this.
QUESTION: Is there anything else you'd like to add before we finish?
NAME: Theo

ANSWER: I'm Tim Reid and I'm a post doctoral researcher in the school of Geo science in Edinburgh University. For the last three years i have been employed on a project looking at arctic snow cover in the north of Scandinavia, in particular in areas where there are forests that are snow covered for at least half of the year. These are important areas because the forest affects the overall reflectance of the surface and this is a very important parameter for climate models and weather prediction models.
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: This project has focused on field work, we have had two big field work campaigns, one in Sweden and one in Finland inside the Arctic Circle where there are large areas of forest cover and the main data set was the solar radiation underneath the forest canopy - so how much sun light was reaching the snow, how much long wave radiation there is in that environment also measure meteorology, temperature, humidity, air pressure and wind speed in the forest and outside the forest to assist in models that will predict snow melt and predict how the atmosphere interacts with the surface. All of which is important for these larger scale models of atmospheric circulation.
QUESTION: The parameters that you use - where do you learn about those parameters and what do you use as your basis for that research?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I have been analyzing data to look at the transmission of the canopy which is essentially, you measure the radiation under the canopy and you measure it outside the canopy and the take a ration of the two.So you get about 50% and 50% of the light.That is the simplest explanation. There are lots of complicated ways of modeling the forest cover and we have collected data on a wide variety of scales. We have a terrestrial laser scanner with us which sends out a laser beam to give you out millions of points and gives you essentially a 3-D representation of the entire forest canopy. As about as detailed as you can possibly get in those sort of surveys and we took lots of hemispherical photographs which were taken from the ground looking up the way which give you a good impression of how much sky is visible from any individual spot. We have some airborne data sets that are available to us. there was a big lydar survey which was done a few years ago which gives canopy height maps over big kilometres scales which we can thenuse to upscale the findings we get and try and get some generalised parameters that can be expanded to look at larger areas. To look at larger scales we can then use satellite data sets. There are satellites such as ISAT or Modus which have several different parameters that those satellites can then measure and then compare to our data to upscale to the arctic as a whole.
QUESTION: So what do you do with the information once you have collected it?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: On a fairly adhoc basis to be honest. For example the airborne lydar data sets was collected on a grant on which one of our co-investigators was one of the co-investigators on that previous grant. That was the NERC aircraft that flew over the area and got that data, so he just passed that data on to us. The Modus data is available through NASA to anyone who applies and it's subject to limitations but all of that information is available from NASA, except when the USA government is shut down, which i found out last week when i was trying to access it.
QUESTION: For the lydar and ISAP Modus data - you got a hold of that data by accessing it from somewhere else. Where do you learn about these data sets and how do you get access to them in order to do your work?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes
QUESTION: Due to the government crisis?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: When you have done your research and analysis and collected your data, what approaches do you take to share that with the community? How do you publish it, what do you do next?
QUESTION: When you have done your research and analysis and collected your data, what approaches do you take to share that with the community? How do you publish it, what do you do next?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes
QUESTION: So later on you, or someone like you could go to NERC and access this information and use it in your research?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes. We have published two papers so far and another two are hopefully coming out quite soon and those are in journals that i guess you'd call traditional journals. One of them quite interestingly was a method i developed for analysing these hemispherical photographs that i spoke about and i submitted it to a journal that i guess was a well respected journal, quite high impact but quite high publication charges as well. It got mixed reviews and in the first round of reviews i ended up rewriting it significantly and realised that there were flaws in the section that all the reviewers had picked out. I actually ended up removing that section and having it a lot shorter. As it happened, that journal asked me to re-submit and i did so. It only got one review back which was very short and it said: i still have reservations about this particular bit but otherwise it's OK. After that the editors decided that this had had too many reviews and they wouldn't accept it now. I found this slightly annoying as i felt i had been humble in accepting the limitations of the initial submission which did have significant weaknesses once they were pointed out to me. I felt slightly let down by the review process of that journal at that time. Anyway we ended up submitting it because by that point i had a bigger more substantial paper which was actually reporting all the data that we collected in the Arctic and it was referencing all that i was describing in the earlier paper. In order to get it out quickly we submitted it to an open journal which my PI recommended as being one that would publish it quickly at a low cost and it got a review which wasn't particularly substantial, although i felt it had been paired down so much by these other reviews that i feel it was a peer reviewed piece of work. But since then i realised that this publisher is on a list of predatory publishers that has come up quite a lot in the science news recently. Many of which will publish papers with no reviews what so ever, as long as you pay them. This is i guess a weakness of open access and makes a lot of academics wary of open access as a concept
QUESTION: In terns of your groups discoveries, do you go on to publish your findings beyond the NERC repository?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I think the whole peer review process is useful as long as your honest and open about what you have done and as a reviewer you are honest and open about your own experience and interpretation because i review a lot of the papers myself and in some cases where I'm not a particular expert but i can give an informed opinion on, then i will honestly say in a review - i might be misunderstanding here but this seems a bit strange to me. This approach that you have used etc etc and i guess you don't want to appear too humble because your offering a professional opinion but it's a difficult balance to strike. I certainly spend quite a lot of time on a review if I'm asked to review a paper. I think, i read that the average is two hours that people spend doing a review which seems crazy to me. I think to properly read a research paper often takes two hours or more and then to write the review would take another two hours. It usually takes half a day or more on reviewing a paper or an evening and it's something that academics are just expect it to do. I do find it useful when I'm publishing papers myself. i think the reviews can often make the paper better. The paper i went onto publish, i was very pleased, it was the longest research paper i had ever written and it was based on two big field campaigns and i had quite a lot of modelling work and i had summarised all that.It was a lot of work to put it all together. The reviews were very thorough. One in particular, the reviewer actually revealed themselves to me and it was someone that i had communicated with over the last few years and it was someone doing similar work and i guess technically is competitor but we exchange ideas and i think that is a very positive aspect of peer review.I actually reviewed one of his papers as well not long ago. I think a lot of outsiders look at peer review and they think it's people with their mates giving each other the benefit of the doubt. You don't give anyone the benefit of the doubt at all. Scientist are there own harshest critics and i think you would only reveal your identity if you were giving a positive review. I have given negative reviews to good friends of mine that have published papers that i thought were a bit weak and in those cases that's were the anonymity is useful. I think people would be less willing to give negative reviews if they had to reveal their identity. It's difficult to draw the line as i guess you should be willing to openly criticise if you're being extremely crtical of something.But editors have to give a decision i guess as editors aren't usually experts on all the papers that come into their journals. They have to trust the reviews that they get.
QUESTION: You got feedback during the publishing of that process and made changes but that there was a cost involved. In the first case quite a high cost and in the second case a low cost. Apart from being let down by that process, what did you find in that process that was actually valuable? Was it useful to get the feedback, or to change your work or was it not useful? Was there anything else occur duing that time that was valuable to you as a scientist?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I guess people are very defensive of their own work and less open to criticism then others. You know in some cases, careers might depend on it so yes it's difficult. You only have to look at Internet forums to see that people are very different in what they write anonymously to how they are in public, and you know you wouldn't necessarily go up to a person and say the same things that you might say in a review. Personally, I'd like to think that i would but i would do it very politely and i try to be polite in the negative reviews that i write. I've had some reviews of my own work from people that aren't that polite but that's up to them. Maybe they're not that polite in person, you never know.
QUESTION: How would you compare the difference between being able to give a negative review anonymously, to say giving the same person a review if you were to meet at a conference? Would that change what you are saying to them as they would know you it was you saying that, perhaps you were in a lecture hall and the work was being presented?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I think you have a lot invested in your own research. It could be a years worth of work that you're reporting in this paper and then if someone says it's rubbish and you feel they haven't fully understood the paper. I guess that might be the fault of what you have written in the paper it's not clear enough what you did, but you can understand that someone might take it that this is a deliberate from a competitor in some cases. I dont' think that's an issue in the field i world in but I'm sure that influences things in other fields. As a reviewer i try to be as humble as possible and say i may I've misunderstood here and maybe i need more information that's not actually in the paper. Can you provide this as in some cases i find it hard to make a judgement on how good the science is because it's not reported in sufficient detail for me to make that judgement.
QUESTION: It is useful from my perspective that you have done a lot of reviewing yourself. Do you have a difference in attitude between when you've had work published and reviewed, and say when you review someone else's work that's been done by them? How do you separate out those two roles and what different approaches do you take? Does having done both help you from the other side? Can you guess what a reviewer might want because you have reviewed?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes. I think there's an issue with non native English speakers. There was a paper by some Chinese authors that i was asked to review but i couldn't make head nor tale of it as the English wasn't good enough and i told the editor it would need to be proof read before i could give a scientific review. That's quite a common occurrence as well
QUESTION: So there's a distinction between if the science was good and the write up of the science was good? Where you may not have been given the information to make the decision?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: 8 years in total
QUESTION: How long have you been a practicing scientist?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I wasn't aware of the predatory publishers when i was doing my PhD. I was focused on the grades and the thesis. I got two papers out of my PhD that were published in well established journals, so that wasn't an issued. There have always been differences in journals, you get some obscure titles. During my PhD i was educated towards the impact factors which i think is what everyone looks to as flawed as that may be there is a number associated with each journal which is valued along with research councils and universities across the board.
QUESTION: Have you noticed a change in the attitude of peer reviews over the course of your career and has it impacted your world at all?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes, it depends on the paper that you're publishing. Sometimes you want something to be specific for people in a particular fields in a specialised field and so you'll publish in a specific journal for a targeted community, you might know the people involved from being at conferences with them and they are the people that will be interested. When I've had a big piece of research based on a bigger time period I've submitted that to bigger journals that are more generic to the Geo sciences area. The geophysical research is the big one that people use when they have findings that are more general and will be interesting to the wider community
QUESTION: Do you find it useful that the journals you publish in can be identified by having a good reputation?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Not that it's easy to get into. The specialist journals are hard to get into.
QUESTION: At the start and now, there is the same sense in the quality of the journal is useful although knowing that a journal is easy to get into might be beneficial in some situations?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I have published a paper with one of these journals. i guess at the time we wanted something to reference on the methods that we had used and so i suppose it's a bit under hand but i felt it had been very well reviewed in the previous journals that i had submitted it to but the editor said it's a particular journal that gets a lot of submissions and turns a lot down so they are looking for any excuse to turn things down. That happens with a lot of journals and mine wasn't up to scratch on the first submission and I'm aware of that but i changed it hugely and made it a lot shorter and more focused and i feel it's a good bit of work and I've presented it in conferences where people have been impressed by it's published in a low impact journal from a predatory publisher but it's out there and it's referenced. I used it to cite in a more respected journal and i referenced it there. So if those more respected journals are willing to use citations of less reputable journals perhaps that's an endemic issue.
QUESTION: The predatory ones, they may hae a lower reputation but there is some other value to publishing with them?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I think I'm subjective. Peers at conferences have been impressed and therefore have the same idea that it's worthwhile work. I have seen examples of other academics who have done a review of a paper which they didn't think was up to scratch and they've rejected it. A few months later they'll see it published in another journal where obviously the author has submitted it again and again with hardly changing anything until they have luck with reviewers. That's disheartening, it's inevitable when reviewing is subjective to a small extent. If they get lucky with a reviewer who hasn't got much time and wants to bash out a review quickly. Which i never always write at least three or four pages in a review. If it's a really good paper the it's easy as usually a page of two will do but usually i do three of four pages.
QUESTION: You got a sense of the quality of the work, however it went through, where ever it was published resulted with work you were happy with? And your peers had the same idea?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Not necessarily, i've looked at lots of published paper and occasionally you'll see ones and wonder how they got published. There is the fact that you need to be subjective about any paper because a lot of it comes from fads: how sexy a bit of science is, if they get a good headline out of it, such as in the Daily Mail - this causes cancer, and this causes cancer. Those factors are always there. There are special issues that journals have where a lot of groups have cobbled together a paper on various work they have done because the journal wants to explore a particular theme at a particular time. I think that's great, it gives people a deadline and a focus to get some of their work out there. The fact that something has been published shouldn't be an automatic stamp of quality. When you read a paper you should make your own judgement then and there. You shouldn't say this should be accepted knowledge. You are essentially reviewing it every time you read it.
QUESTION: You have said that you and colleagues have thought that some papers haven't been good but they have been published elsewhere and that there have been few changes made. What is it about the published paper that enables you to think that it's low quality,and the people that see it published will think it's low quality too? Or does the fact that it's been published give it authority?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Data is a different exercise. We have been careful to document all the quality control for the data sensors. You have the sensors sitting out there in the arctic sitting on top of a snow pack some of them will sink into the pack so they aren't level any more and we were checking them every day and updating, and brushing off snow fall. So we were taking detailed notes, updating data and discarding data where the sensors were covered with snow or at an unreasonable angle. We have documented that as an appendix in the published paper. We can refer to that. For bigger scales sets, NASA have lots of stuff. They have certain alga rhythms that they use to process data from the satellites which are open to interpretation. They do there best to filter data. When there's cloud cover and they're not seeing the surface.That's complicated, we trust NASA. Colleagues of mine are working on seeing how good NASA data is and use data from the ground and from the aircraft which are closer to the ground to validate satellite data and to check that you get a decent between the satellite speed and what you see on the actual ground. Quality control, being aware of what you're looking at and the limitations of it as well.
QUESTION: How does that apply to the data sets that you mentioned at the start of the interview? When you access them, some must be impossible to check so how do you balance wanting to know it's correct with not being able to?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: Yes
QUESTION: All of the information that you given on collecting your data, you would expect that someone else reading this would build up that trust where it's not possible to recreate that experiment?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: In terms of accessing papers, one of these big journals sells their papers in bundles to libraries where only two of three of those journals are of interest to the university but you have to buy the huge chunk and the mount it costs libraries to have this research available is ridiculous. Academics are getting angry that these big journals are making big profits based on a model where they are still printing hundreds of thousands of copies of journals. I don't remember the last time i went to the library to look at a hard copy of a paper. They are all almost available on line. Running a website when the infrastructures are in place have these facilities in place where you have the web of science to access papers. A journal receives the papers, send them to reviewers which often the author recommends. Submitting a paper can take hours, you have to paste the abstract, the authors and all their affiliations, key words and highlights within 140 characters. It's exasperating. Then you have to upload all your figures separately, so it's almost at a point where they can press a button and say format into our journal style and there it is. It's sent to reviewers who work for free, then there's editors who work for free or a small allowance and i don't know what the journals do to earn these large profits and why it should cost three thousand pounds to have something open access especially when it's paid for by the tax payer a lot of the time.
QUESTION: With the work that you have done and published and the work you might hope to do after that do you see any big issues in the future with access to information you need or your ability to publishing? Where would you publish, how will it be measured, do you have any concerns for the future?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: At the moment I'm employed by someone else on a grant that is run by them and so if my PI is keen to publish in a particular journal or for a particular impact factor which consists a bit of money to publish in, then i'm committed to publishing with them. Other ones you don't pay but then the library pay huge amounts of money to have them. I try to put any papers i have published on my website which i think is common practice. If someone wanted a copy of my paper because they don't have institutional access i would pass it on.
QUESTION: Will that have any impact on your own work in the future, given that a journal can't exist unless a scientist gives them something to publish? Does that have any bearing on what you might do? Will you have to publish your own work?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: In the future, if we could identify an open access publishers that are thorough in their peer reviews process and don't cost a fortune.Then i would submit papers to them. I have my career to think about but the fact is that things are still judged on impact factor and some of these new journals that are open access don't cost a fortune don't have the impact factor yet, but hopefully if some of the younger researchers can ignore impact factors and say if you can publish the reviews on line, which quite a a lot are starting to do. Then i will certainly go for those. To be honest i think some of the bigger journals are having to accept that their fees are unreasonable. I had one published last year in a big journal that was based on a previous job on a grant that had expired and we didn't have the money to pay for it. We has some rich Swiss co-authors that agreed to pay some of the fees and they agreed to cut the fee to a third of the initial cost as we didn't have the money
QUESTION: Do you have anything else to add?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: I'm glad to have that paper published because it's a journal that has been accepted as a high quality journal for a long time but in the future i would like these well established journals to adapt to a cheaper more open access model and accept that the fees are nor reasonable and that the profit margins for their shareholders are absurd and that everything can be done to a lower price to the academics and the tax payer. That's the way everything should go in my opinion
QUESTION: You still want the quality but the price seems high?
NAME: Tim

ANSWER: My name is Tom Olihoek and I'm a microbiologist in training, a molecular microbiologist and after having finished the research i entered open access at about two years ago because i contacted Peter Murray Rust of the OKF and then since then I'm involved with the open access and the OAKF activities.
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: So i founded a company called Codex Consultancy and there i try to find people who need open access consultants and the first customer that i got being with Codex Consult is the World Bank and since then I'm trying to get other people to ask me to do things for them. So yes I'm a freelance consultant for open science and open access at the moment.
QUESTION: So are you currently a freelancer or do you work for the OKF? What is your current position?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: The trigger for this was that i have to try to be involved with Malaria research at a late stage of my career. But anyway i have been doing some activities in the lab and I've been doing research but i saw that there is a lot of open science going on and in the whole set up of what are you going to do research, publishing etc i found the topic of open access and open science especially for Malaria research very attractive and then i shared a moment about three years ago. I decided to stop doing the research and trying to promote open access and open science especially for improving access to health information for the developing world.
QUESTION: In the last few years then, in the work that you've been preforming, what is it in particular about open access or open science that has led you into that field? Why have you discovered that it's been useful for you to get into something that's open rather than just doing science?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: The people that i was involved with at the time was the Malaria world community and those are very many scientists especially in the developing world and so i did not really have access to papers that had been published in nature or in molecular micro biology or else a few titles of any sort. The man that i met doing the research for Malaria was Matt Close and he is a well known researcher here in the Netherlands and he set up a web site a few years before for the Malaria researchers in the whole world, the Malaria world and he made a listing of all the relevant literature that came out weekly and we found of course that lots of this literature is not accessible to many of the leaders of the Malaria world platform and then we naturally came to try and find the open access information and try and do things so that we can multiface Malaria researchers to publish in the open access journals. So that's when i decided to go after that goal.
QUESTION: So did you find then ,was it an issue for you trying to access information that you required, or was it an issue for people that you were working with trying to access information? Where did the issue arise of not being able to get hold of what you needed?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: There were a lot of changes especially in the last two years. I think that the years before there were not many changes, There was a bit of change but especially the last two years. The attention for open access has been growing enormously and it's just lucky that i have witnessed the whole development from being virtually known to a small group of scientists and students to something almost a word movement now. Of course there are lots of people that are not so for open access at the moment but it's really gained enormous attention. Also in the Netherlands politically and politically in the USA and UK and i think that being with the Open Knowledge Federation, involved as an open access co-ordinator for activities has helped me a lot to make the connections that i need to be able to work in this specific field.
QUESTION: So how has that been going and have you seen much of a change in the last few years? Have you seen issues arise that have made things worse or better?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: Yes the open access, Open Knowledge Foundation has been the, has still a key role in bringing people together.
QUESTION: So the ability i guess to be able to talk to people and co-ordinate with people through those groups enabled you to meet others and move forward with this?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: I have found very many different people especially when i went to the to South Africa for a conference in open access that it was because i had made connection through the Open Knowledge Foundation with people that were involved in this conference and the people that i met there were especially people that didn't have enough access to the relevant literature in their fields and not only biomedical but also in geography or in botany, all kinds of fields. So i have experienced access problems with literature but most of the time i have by passed these by accessing the literature through library accounts of my friends. But that's not the way that you want to do science. So there were some key figures that i met, especially Matt Todd who did open science for Malaria and who is a real proponant for doing science the way he does it. Bringing everything in the open, the notebooks the lab note books, the ideas and he says that everything i do should be openly done and should be open access and everybody can see how much he has attained and how many results he has obtained by working with everybody that is interested to work with him. So i met a lot of people. Some did have access but say were idealistically in favour of open access. Other people were very much against the open access in journals but only open access for repositories. So there are lots of different people that perhaps also chase different ideas on open access still.
QUESTION: What have you found then working, for meeting other people through this network obviously you would need to explain how you found this issue yourself with the people that you were wanting to work with not having access. With the new people that you met through the network through the OKF, what was it that you had in common with them? Say the other scientist that you mentioned earlier on and then the wider community that built up. Have you found that they've all experienced the same problems, or are there slightly different goals and what's been the most common thing that has allowed you to build a community around this idea?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: I think there is still a diference in opinion on what open access is but with a small, it's a small group of course, if we take the Berlin declaration and the Budapest declaration as the definition of open access then things are not very difficult. Only most of the organizations that want to say we are going for open access, in the first place what they do is offer free reading and there is nothing done in the way of you being able to use anything that you published and you can download the articles especially that is what you want if there's a lot of literature and it's not open access in the sense of the Budapest declaration then everybody can for example read a thousand articles in my field of Malaria but you don't have the time to do that so what you really want to be able to do is to download lots of stuff and have it treated by computers by text mining and by data mining and see what you come up with and as long as that is not possible, we don't obtain the goal of open access i guess and there are a lot of problems at the moment there. Different parties wanting different things.
QUESTION: How difficult has it been then for you to try to align those interests if there is lots of different ideas of open access and lots of different ideals for what people are aiming at, do you feel people are still heading in the right direction? Or does it start to derail quite a lot when people have different opinions on what open access is?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: Yes. I think that what we want to do is spread the word that open access is not about being able to read something only but you will have to be able to take it with you. Like going to a book shop. It's an open access book shop. You should be able to take all the books out of the exhibition that they have and you can read in it and you can do things but you are not allowed to take it with you unless you pay. That is not the way that we want to do it. So i think that my work as i have it in my mind is to try and convince people of the principles of open access. That it has to be completely unrestricted and reusable, being able to text mine being able to data mine lots of information that is somewhere available. The other problem is not only that you have access to the stuff but that you will be able to find things easily and then you can hear people saying - look if you put something in a repository in open access then everyone can find it using Google or something and then you put it on your computer and you can just read it. But my feeling is that that's not the way it should be. For example again for Malaria there are all kinds of articles in twenty or two thousand repositories all round the world and then nobody is able to pick out those articles and go through all of them and do text mining etc but everybody has to go to this specific place and try then to see if the computer is up and if you can have access to that free database and then spend the time reading it and not being able to do anything else. That is not what we want.
QUESTION: So in the work that you're doing at the moment, are these the kinds of issues that you're seeing that you're having to work on and apart from just having access to reading material then there's this problem of doing useful things with it, does that come up in your work?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: For myself i would say that i am completely in favour of open access in the sense of putting something on line being that it's available for everybody to download and do anything with it that they want. Except they have to just do an attribution to get some of the work and if it's me, then they attribute me and if it's some of the co-workers then they also attribute the co-workers. That's the only thing. The sense of the CCBY licence is OK for me. Completely OK for me. I am also at ease with it. Not that i talk to myself that i have to accept it because i have come to the conclusion that i can gain a lot more by putting these things available out in the open and getting a lot of response. That builds on my work, that it will improve enormously in the way that i can't do it on my way.
QUESTION: So then in your work trying to advocate for making sure that people understand it's not just a case of reading but to take that work and use it and do something else with it, to put it through a computer and build on it. Have you yourself or have you encountered in other people a difference in opinion when it comes to their own work?. If you publish your own work what do you believe that other people should be able to do with that work and does that have an impact on your thoughts of open access?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: Yes. I think that it really is for the best interests of science. Scientists if they put aside these ideas of thinking yes i want to have access to all the work that people did except that i don't put my work out in the open, that is not going to work.
QUESTION: So you're not doing it just because it's an ideal or a good idea in that sense?. You are doing it because it's making your work better?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: think that there is a possibility that if you do some work for a company and you devise a protocol to, for example - how you make stem cells or something like that. Then this protocol is a valuable thing for a company. They don't want to have all the ins and outs published on the Internet. So you have to patent it and I'm not against patenting things. But patenting things is quite another thing from open access. I can understand that there are people working in science or in other things that take a patent on some methods or some specific publications but if you want to advance science as a whole enterprise then you should share as much as possible.
QUESTION: What do you think would be the particular issue there then? Say you were to make a piece of work and you didn't make it available yourself, how would you describe that piece of work, how would you build on that or would you see it a being not really available, not a submission towards progress? I'm trying to get an idea of what happens to these works that are not shared?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: No. They are not incompatible. Again Mathew taught in Australia demonstrating that it's not necessary at all to go to the USA holding secrets on the things that he does. I think that he himself is even convinced that he doesn't need to take patents on things that he develops because in his mind he develops a procedure for example and then he puts it in the open and then people somewhere in the world are improving or giving him ideas on how to improve on his methods. So he does and he gains a lot of trust and a good network of people around him and then in the end there is a method that he uses to obtain the goals that he wants and lots of other people in the world that work with him, can work with his methods and speed up the whole process. So he doesn't use patents at all. i can understand that there are people working in companies doing science that to a certain degree if they are involved with patents, that is different from the open access thing that we are talking about here.
QUESTION: So the distinction between work that is for the advancement of science and off shoots that are for say commercial use, the two aren't necessarily incompatible?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: I think there are two groups of people actually. Students that you talk with are very much in favour of open access. In the sense of the Berlin declaration and we have seen in the last Berlin conference for the young investigators that there was a huge platform for doing things in the open access way and there was also a lot of attention in the whole world in particular congress conference. But if you go to Africa for example. South Africa, Ethiopia there are scientists working on things and they are very unhappy with the situation where they have to put their work out in the open because they say then Mr X will take all my work and i don't get paid for it and i will now not get promotion and all these kinds of things. It's a big issue. They are very afraid of giving their ideas and their work and putting it in the open and of course that is also the first reaction that people have here in the Northern Hemisphere, say someone who is not a scientist and you tell then these ideas and then all these other people can steal your idea. That is the way that people react in the first place and after some thinking they say well it doesn't have to be that way of course if you do a discussion. I really go through the moods of - but why do you want to protect your ideas do you think they are great, do you think that other people couldn't have those ideas? and then they say no, but my promotion and my recognition but if you put it on the Internet then everybody knows you were the one to do it because it's your name and even having CCBY Licenses, everybody is obliged to recognise you as the author so what's the problem because if you do that then you can have a lot of interaction with other people who perhaps admire your work or find something that they have an eye for to improve. So the only thing that can happen with your work is that it gets better, it will never get worse. That is the turning point for most of them. Except for Africa people who really find a lot right with what can happen with their work.
QUESTION: When you are seeking to do your advocacy for open access, there are obviously issues around the difference of what's specifically open access. You've made it clear that there are simple definitions that could be used and if those were taken forward then things would be more straight forward and you think better as well such as the Berlin or Budapest declarations. How easy or hard have you found it to engage with new people that you want to get involved with this when it comes down to these small differences? Have you found people react badly when they're given these choices or is it small differences of opinion, or do they get involved in these discussions? Does it attract them more or is it off putting? How do you get round that issue?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: I think that the scientific enterprise is very competitive in the USA in the UK and in Europe but also in Africa and in Africa there is another factor that adds to this and that is they have a slight inferiority complex more or less that everything they do is perhaps not as worthy as what other people in the northern universities in the USA, UK or Europe. So if they have something that they think is great they are very reluctant to put these ideas somewhere in an open access journal because they have the feeling that they loose things. That if they give something away it's very bad for their self esteem. I can understand it completely and of course it has something to do with their jobs. If people who give them a job or who are in charge of putting them for another job in the next few years are looking at what they have published in closed access journals then of course they will be very afraid that they have missed the boat more or less. But if these people of the universities could look at the impact of the work that their employees have in the world. As they would look at old metrics and not if it's in nature or science, then they would gain a lot of points because you could see the impact they had is because of their work and not because of where it's published and that could also break the spell between protecting my things that i did myself and sharing it with other scientists in the world.
QUESTION: So it seems that what you aim at then is getting to people's fundamental ideas of why they are doing this activity and then try to bring it out to be obvious that actually to do that activity the best way that they want to do it, you just have to convince them i guess that this approach is actually better than what they are used to but that is still aiming for the the same goal . When you are working with people in Africa, is the reluctance down to, is it harder to make a living for scientists there, what makes it harder there in your experience for the people there to accept that kind of argument?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: Yes of course it's because the officials are using those rules.
QUESTION: So it's not so much that things are widely different for those people that you meet, it's just that they are still in the process of trying to justify their work and the traditional justification has been closed access journals and so that's how they get their recognition?
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: Yes but i said that there is perhaps also a small feeling of being lower in the hierarchy tree or something.
QUESTION: It's still true as well of a lot of people in Europe and America?.
NAME: Tom

ANSWER: For the next time that i am directly involved in open access journals as an advisor but i also do work in separating open access spectrum method of the public library of science and the point is that we really want to have people seeing what kind of rights they have if they read some works that are listed in a journal and it's a very easy way if you can quantify say the open access list of an article or of a journal and that is what we try to do in the collaboration with the public library of science, Cottage Labs, direct of open access journals and we did a pilot project just finished that did rather good research i think. So what i hope to do is a full implementation of this OAS of open exospectrum methods in the direct of open access journals as of July or something and apart from that what i hope to do is make open access work more accessible by organising it better according to topics and also making it more accessible by being able to say how good some work is because if you are a scientist and you want to know something then you go to for example a place where you can find information ideally and ideally all the information is there, then you find the information that you want and you make sure that it's open access and you can do anything with it that you want and for that you really need to be able to know to get it open access in the sense that you need it. Plus you need to know that the work, the articles, the information you're seeking is available in this location and that you don't have to start searching for half a year all over the world because they missed something. So it's a question of organizing databases with open access information as full, as complete as possible and of assessing the quality of the information that people can make the choice of the best sources of the information that they need and those two aspects of organizing databases and communities and organizing the assessment of the quality can be interlinked because if you have a group of people that are in need of some information because they work in that field, then they can also judge how good the information is, as long as the assurance that the information is there is also complete. Those two projects i hope to do together with the Open Knowledge Foundation in the Open Science Development Group and in collaboration with a network platform for scientists which is called Science Open. That's a new organization in Berlin and what they want is to have scientists that visit the site that know them. They have all the information they have in open access there to be discussed, to be judged, to be assessed, to be used for collaboration etc etc. So i think that the Science Open platform offers a lot of possibilities for me to go after these ideals and i think that they are ideals that i just talk are also shared by the founders of that site in the open platform. So that is the plan for the next few years.
